name: Admiral
saying:
Only quitters give up.
頑固一徹
description: Admiral is a cranky bird villager that appears in Animal Crossing series titles until Doubutsu no Mori e+ and returns in Animal Crossing: New Leaf - Welcome amiibo. His name and initial quote are both sailing-related - admiral being a title given to the supreme commander of a ship, which are often stern and obstinate, in reference to his cranky personality. "Aye aye" is a phrase meaning "yes" or "yes sir", or further meaning "Yes, I have received the instructions, understood them, and will carry them out."

name: Agent S
saying:
You gotta put the pedal to the metal!
I'm gonna, like, save the world!
疾きこと風の如し
description: Agent S is a peppy squirrel villager from the Animal Crossing series. Like the other superheroes, she was introduced in Doubutsu no Mori e+, and then reappeared in Animal Crossing: Wild World, Animal Crossing: City Folk, and Animal Crossing: New Leaf. She is one of only three superheroines (the others being Rocket and Filly), and the only one to appear in games before Animal Crossing: New Leaf. She may be Kid Cat's sidekick, because of her initial phrase "sidekick" and their Japanese names (Kid Cat's Japanese name is #1 while Agent S's Japanese name is #2).  The "S" in her name may stand for "squirrel" or "sidekick".

name: Agnes
saying: You reap what you sow.
description: Agnes is a sisterly pig villager in the Animal Crossing series. She first appeared in Animal Crossing: New Leaf. Her Japanese (and, in turn, her English name) is a portmanteau of アグー, a breed of black pig native to Okinawa, and the name Agnes. Her catchphrase is a reference to the sniffing noises a pig makes and her Japanese catchphrase, "ブフフ", may be a pun on onomatopoeias for the sound a pig makes, ブーブー, and laughter, ふふふ. Her saying may be a pun on sow (an adult female pig).

name: Al
saying: Life is a buffet - always go back for seconds.
description: Al is a lazy, gorilla villager from the Animal Crossing series whose first appearance is in Animal Crossing: City Folk.

name: Alfonso
saying:
Slow and steady wins the race.
We're friends, so I won't gnaw on your legs, even though I'm starving.
寝る子は育つ
多睡的孩子长得快
description: Alfonso is a lazy alligator villager from the Animal Crossing series. He has appeared in every Animal Crossing game to date. He appears in Doubutsu no Mori (film) as a major character and Yu's best friend. His catchphrase, "it'sa me," is a reference to the famous Nintendo character, Mario.

name: Alice
saying:
Treat others as you would like to be treated.
I like having you around.
description: Alice is a normal, koala villager in the Animal Crossing series. She first appeared in Doubutsu no Mori e+. When she first moves into the town she uses the phrase, "guvnor". Her name is based on the city of Alice Springs, Australia.

name: Alli
saying:
Think before you act.
The most important parts of any ensemble are the purse and shoes.
口は心のものさし
以口量心
description: Alli is a snooty, alligator villager who has appeared in nearly all of the Animal Crossing series games, except for Animal Crossing: Pocket Camp. Her name is simply a shortening of alligator, her species, and her initial phrase is the sound an alligator makes.

name: Amelia
saying:
Pampering yourself is as important as food, water, and shelter!
同じ羽色の鳥は集まる
description: Amelia is an eagle villager with a snooty personality from the Animal Crossing series. Her name is derived from Amelia Earhart, who was a noted American aviation pioneer. Amelia was also the only female eagle in the entire Animal Crossing series prior to Animal Crossing: New Leaf, in which Celia was introduced.

name: Anabelle
saying:
Dance like no one's watching!
I'll remember you even when I'm famous!
description: Anabelle is a peppy, anteater villager in the Animal Crossing series. She was introduced in Animal Crossing: Wild World.

name: Anchovy
saying:
Why do today what you can put off until tomorrow.
I'm hungry.
明日できることは今日しない
description: Anchovy is a lazy, bird villager that appears in the Animal Crossing series. His initial phrase is the word "churp", an onomatopoeia for the noise birds make, and a burping sound. In Animal Crossing his initial phrase has one more "u" than in the sequels.

name: Angus
saying:
Even strong men cry.
弁慶の泣き所
description: Angus is a cranky bull villager from the Animal Crossing series. He debuted in Doubutsu no Mori e+, appearing as one of six starter cards bundled with the game, alongside Walker, Maggie, Rod, Merry, and Willow, respectively. His name derives from the "Aberdeen Angus" breed of cow, hence his Scottish catchphrase. It may also be derived from "angus beef", a brand of cow beef.

name: Anicotti
saying: The walls have ears.
description: Anicotti is a peppy, mouse villager in the Animal Crossing series. Her name is based on manicotti, a type of pasta. Her catchphrase, "cannoli", means "little tube" in Italian and is also an Italian dessert. Anicotti was absent in Animal Crossing: Wild World and Animal Crossing: City Folk, but returned in Animal Crossing: New Leaf.

name: Ankha
saying: All that glitters is not gold.
description: Ankha is a snooty cat villager who made her Animal Crossing series debut in Animal Crossing, and has appeared in almost every game since then, except for Animal Crossing: Wild World and Animal Crossing: Pocket Camp. In Animal Crossing, she is an islander, whereas from City Folk onwards, she is a villager. Her name is based on the ankh, which is the Egyptian hieroglyphic character that reads "life." Her catchphrase relates to her arrogant "snooty" personality, by saying "me," and a sound a cat makes, "meow." Her Japanese catchphrase, Kufufu, is a combination of the Pharaoh Khufu, and ufufu, a Japanese onomatopoeia for laughter. Egyptians worshiped cats, and had a cat god, which may be where the idea for Ankha's design came from.

name: Annalisa
saying: Home is where the heart is.
description: Annalisa is a normal anteater villager in the Animal Crossing series. She first appeared in Animal Crossing: New Leaf. Her name is likely derived from "anteater".

name: Annalise
saying: Let gossip in one ear and out the other.
description: Annalise is a snooty horse who appears in Animal Crossing, and Doubutsu no Mori e+, as an islander. After her absence from Animal Crossing: Wild World and Animal Crossing: City Folk, she returned as a villager in Animal Crossing: New Leaf. Her Japanese catchphrase, Sava, is the Japanese pronunciation of the French greeting, "Ça va". Due to her being an islander in Animal Crossing and Doubutsu no Mori e+, she has a fruit allergy. She loves pears and is allergic to oranges.

name: Antonio
saying: Always go for the burn!
description: Antonio is a jock, anteater villager from the Animal Crossing series. His name could be a play on the word anteater, since Antonio starts with the same few letters. His initial catchphrase is "honk", referring to his nose. He appears on the front of the Animal Crossing: City Folk game box, holding a net.

name: Apollo
saying:
What goes up must come down.
I'm not bald! I've just got fine feathers, that's all!
能ある鷹は爪を隠す
description: Apollo is a cranky, eagle villager in the Animal Crossing series who first appears in Doubutsu no Mori. His name possibly came from Apollo 11, the first spacecraft launched by the United States to land a man on the moon, and the Apollo Space Program itself. He is also a bald eagle, a symbol of the United States and in the Great Seal, which ties in with his birthday being July 4th - Independence Day. He also appears in Doubutsu no Mori (film) as a minor character.

name: Apple
saying:
One rotten apple spoils the barrel.
朱に交われば赤くなる
description: Apple is a peppy, hamster villager in the Animal Crossing series. She first appeared in Animal Crossing: New Leaf. Her name is derived from her red and pink colors, which resemble an apple.

name: Astrid
saying:
The apple doesn't fall far from the tree.
親に似ぬ子は鬼子
description: Astrid is a snooty kangaroo villager, who appears in all games in the Animal Crossing series except for Animal Crossing: Wild World. Her name is derived from astrology, the study of stars. Her initial phrase, "my pet", refers to her joey.

name: Audie
saying: Be the kind of person your future self won't regret having been.
description: Audie is a peppy wolf villager who first appeared in Animal Crossing: New Horizons, and is currently the only peppy wolf to date. Her English name may originate from an 87 year-old woman with 3,500+ hours in Animal Crossing: New Leaf, who is named Audrey, and called her player character Audie.[1]

name: Aurora
saying:
Always keep your cool.
Just keep your cool.
渡る世間に鬼はない
description: Aurora is a normal penguin villager in the Animal Crossing series. She is named after the Aurora borealis, which can be seen in the skies above the Earth's poles, where most species of penguin live in the South Pole. Her initial phrase comes from pronouncing "baby" while shivering, which happens when words are pronounced usually in cold weather or climates. She has appeared in every Animal Crossing game to date.

name: Ava
saying:
Early to bed, early to rise.
早寝早起き、病知らず
description: Ava is a normal chicken from the Animal Crossing series. Her name comes from the word ova, the Latin word for eggs, which chickens lay. It is also possible that her name comes from the word "avian", meaning bird. Her catchphrase, "beaker", possibly originates from the word, beak. Ava was absent in Animal Crossing: Wild World and Animal Crossing: City Folk.

name: Avery
saying:
What goes around comes around.
瑠璃も玻璃も照らせば光る
description: Avery is a cranky eagle villager who was debuted in Doubutsu no Mori e+ and was absent in Animal Crossing: Wild World. His name comes from "aviary", a place for keeping birds and from the bird class called "aves". His initial phrase sounds like the noise an eagle or another bird of prey makes.

name: Axel
saying:
Do not compare a fly with an elephant.
歯を見せることが笑うことではない
description: Axel is a jock elephant villager in the Animal Crossing series. His first appearance is in Animal Crossing, but he was absent in Animal Crossing: Wild World. He later appeared in Animal Crossing: City Folk. His name is a play on "XL", as in "extra large". His initial phrase is a play on the word "honk". He appeared on the cover of Animal Crossing: Let's Go To The City for PAL areas.

name: Baabara
saying:
Don't just follow the flock.
I'm so soft that I don't even need a pillow!
description: Baabara is a sheep villager with a snooty personality who has appeared in all of the Animal Crossing series games so far. Her name is a play on words of the name 'Barbara', and the sound sheep make, which is "baa". Combining the two makes "Baabara". Her initial phrase, "daahling", is also a joke on the noise sheep make, and the word "darling". Her Japanese initial phrase, andu, is the Japanese pronunciation of the French words un and duex, meaning "one" and "two," which is a play on her Japanese name, Trois, the French word for "three."

name: Bam
saying: Get while the getting's good.
description: Bam is a deer villager in the Animal Crossing series, and is currently the only jock deer. He debuted in Animal Crossing: New Leaf, and was one of the first villagers announced for the release of the game. His name is likely a reference to the famous deer, Bambi.

name: Bangle
saying: Don't blink or you'll miss it.
description: Bangle is a peppy tiger villager from the Animal Crossing series. She first appeared in Animal Crossing, but was absent from Animal Crossing: Wild World and Animal Crossing: City Folk, not reappearing until Animal Crossing: New Leaf. Her name comes from the Bengal tiger, a subspecies of Tiger commonly native to India and southern Asia. Bangle was also the only female tiger in the Animal Crossing series, prior to when New Leaf introduced Bianca and Claudia.

name: Barold
saying: Please DO feed the bears!
description: Barold is a cub villager in the Animal Crossing series. He first appeared in Animal Crossing: New Leaf. His name is a pun on "bear" and a common name, "Harold".

name: Bea
saying: The perfect pair complements each other.
description: Bea is a normal dog villager from the Animal Crossing series, originally appearing in Animal Crossing and Doubutsu no Mori e+, and returned in Animal Crossing: New Leaf's Welcome amiibo update. Bea's name is likely derived from "Beagle", a breed of dog, while her catchphrase refers to Bingo, a popular children's song involving a dog of that name. It is also the name of a matching game commonly played by elders. Bea's Japanese name may refer to her fur color, which is colored similarly to a bagel.

name: Beardo
saying: Ladies first!
description: Beardo is a smug, bear villager in the Animal Crossing series that first appeared in Animal Crossing: New Leaf. His name is a combination of the words "Bear", his species; and "beard". His Japanese name, Baird, sounds similar to both words. His picture quote may be a reference to his smug personality.

name: Beau
saying:
You snooze, you lose.
来年のことを言えば　鬼が笑う
description: Beau is a lazy deer villager in the Animal Crossing series. He first appeared in Animal Crossing: New Leaf. A "beau" is a male romantic interest, male admirer, or a fashionable young man. It originates as a French term; "beau" is the masculine version of "beautiful". His initial phrase refers to a salt block, an item that hunters and people use to attract antelopes. Appearance-wise, Beau is very similar to an antelope, a deer-like creature common in many parts of Africa and Eurasia, although Antelope themselves are more related to Cows than actual deer.

name: Becky
saying:
A fool and his Bells are soon parted.
白豆腐の拍子木
description: Becky is a chicken villager with a snooty personality in the Animal Crossing series. She made her first appearance in Doubutsu no Mori e+ and later in Animal Crossing: City Folk and Animal Crossing: New Leaf.

name: Bella
saying:
A head shot is worth a thousand words.
Would you like my autograph?
大声は里耳に入らず
description: Bella is a peppy mouse villager in the Animal Crossing series. As a peppy villager, she will appear excitable and friendly towards the player. She makes her debut appearance in Doubutsu no Mori e+. Her initial phrase relates to other mouse villagers and her species, which make the sound "squeak" or "eek."

name: Benedict
saying:
Don't put all your eggs in one basket.
Bok bok bok? Just kidding. A huh huh huh!
杯中の蛇影
description: Benedict is a chicken villager with a lazy personality from the Animal Crossing series. His name comes from the meal, "eggs benedict", which consists of a poached egg placed with bacon on an English muffin and covered in Hollandaise sauce. His name could also be a reference to Benedict Arnold, a fighter in the American Revolutionary war who betrayed General Washington.

name: Benjamin
saying: A good dog deserves a good treat.
description: Benjamin is a lazy dog villager in the Animal Crossing series. He first appeared in Animal Crossing: New Leaf.

name: Bertha
saying:
The best part of spring is the picnics!
花より団子
description: Bertha is a normal hippo villager from the Animal Crossing series, appearing in most of the games except for Animal Crossing: Wild World, Animal Crossing: City Folk, and Animal Crossing: Pocket Camp. Her name refers to "Big Bertha", a name commonly given to something that is unusually large, much like how hippos are large animals. Her Japanese name refers to red bean paste, also known as anko; this relates to her Japanese favorite saying, "dango over flowers", as dango is commonly made with red bean paste. She shares her catchphrase with Zucker, a lazy octopus villager.

name: Bettina
saying: No time like the present!
description: Bettina is a normal, mouse villager who makes her first appearance in Animal Crossing: City Folk. As a normal villager, she will appear calm, friendly, and hospitable towards the player.  Her initial catchphrase, "eekers", is a reference to the squeaking sound made by mice.

name: Bianca
saying: There is such a thing as love at first sight.
description: Bianca is a peppy tiger villager in the Animal Crossing series, first appearing in Animal Crossing: New Leaf. Bianca, alongside Claudia, is notably the first female tiger since Bangle to appear in an Animal Crossing series title, also sharing Bangle's Peppy personality. Bianca's name is Italian for “white”, referring to the color of her fur. It is also the Japanese name of a snooty wolf villager and the German name of a snooty cat villager.

name: Biff
saying:
Eighth place is just the seventh loser.
開いた口にぼた餅
description: Biff is a jock, hippo villager from the Animal Crossing series. He made his first appearance in Doubutsu no Mori. The name "Biff" comes from the adjective "buff", a slang term for someone with strong muscles, which references his jock personality.

name: Big Top
saying:
A big nose never spoiled a handsome face.
World domination!
description: Big Top is a lazy, elephant villager in the Animal Crossing series. He first appears in Doubutsu no Mori e+ and also Animal Crossing: Wild World and Animal Crossing: City Folk. His name may be a reference to the main arena of a circus, the big top, where elephants are mainly situated in a circus. It may also be a joke on the size of elephants, who are large mammals, or "big" in this case. His initial phrase, "villain", plays along with his superhero charm and appearance. Some believe he may be a villain to the four other superhero villagers, Kid Cat, Agent S, Rocket, and Filly, with his picture in Animal Crossing: Wild World quote being "World domination!" and his phrase could be a tag placed on him to mark him as the evildoer in the game, though it depends on opinion.

name: Bill
saying:
Even though there's no 'I' in team, there is a 'me'!
Even though there's no 'I' in team, there's no 'everybody' either!
description: Bill is a jock, duck villager in the Animal Crossing series. He appeared on the cover of Animal Crossing, in the background, appearing to be walking up to the house. He also appears on the cover of Animal Crossing: City Folk, appearing to be holding a fishing rod with a black bass. His name comes from the name of the duck's beak, a bill. He shares the same catchphrase with Drake, another duck villager.

name: Billy
saying:
Old dogs can learn new tricks.
アクティブ・エイジ
description: Billy is a jock goat villager introduced in Doubutsu no Mori. He appeared in the original games, and was absent in Animal Crossing: Wild World and Animal Crossing: City Folk, before returning in Animal Crossing: New Leaf - Welcome amiibo. His name is a pun on the term "billy goat". He is a friendly villager who often needs the player to carry out errands for him. His catchphrase, "dagnaabit," comes from "dag nab it," an exclamation of dismay. Additionally, Billy's name is also the Japanese name of Gruff, another goat villager.

name: Biskit
saying:
Let sleeping dogs lie.
目は真実を見、耳は嘘を聞く
description: Biskit is a lazy dog villager in the Animal Crossing series. He first appeared in Doubutsu no Mori. His name may be related to dog biscuits or biscuits in general, which relates to the food interests of lazy villagers. His catchphrase however, "dawg," relates to his species, dog.

name: Bitty
saying:
Necessity is the mother of invention.
必要は良い忠告である
description: Bitty is a snooty, hippo villager in the Animal Crossing series. Following her initial appearance, Bitty would remain absent in the entire series until Animal Crossing: New Leaf - Welcome amiibo, returning with several other hippos previously added in the original game. This was followed by an appearance in Animal Crossing: Pocket Camp, as the only Hippo to appear in said game, prior to September 22nd, 2018, in which Rocco was also added.

name: Blaire
saying:
Practice makes perfect.
My tail looks extra fluffy in this picture.
女心と南風
description: Blaire is a snooty squirrel villager from the Animal Crossing series that resembles a skunk. She has appeared in every game so far. Blaire's name is a portmanteau of the word "black", the color of her fur; and the given name "Claire".

name: Blanche
saying: Nothing beats personal experience.
description: Blanche is a snooty, ostrich villager in the Animal Crossing series who first appeared in Animal Crossing: New Leaf. Her name is the French word for the color white, a nod to her main color.

name: Bluebear
saying:
Candy makes the world go 'round.
I enjoy tap dancing and raspberry jam!
description: Bluebear is a peppy, cub villager in the Animal Crossing series. She is named after her color and species, and also the fruit, the blueberry (which relates to her catchphrase, "peach"). Her Japanese name may come from nuigurumi, meaning a stuffed toy. Bluebear also shares her Japanese catchphrase with Megumi, a peppy dog villager from Doubutsu no Mori e+, though Bluebear's is spelled in katakana, while Megumi's is in hiragana.

name: Bob
saying:
You only live once...or nine times.
I'm a cat. Chillin' is in my blood, man.
豚に真珠
description: Bob is a lazy villager who has appeared in every game of the Animal Crossing series. His name is probably a reference to bobcats. His initial phrase, "pthhpth," may be a reference to the sound a cat makes when coughing up a hairball.

name: Bonbon
saying: Hindsight is always 20/20.
description: Bonbon is a peppy rabbit villager who first appeared in Animal Crossing: New Leaf. Her name can refer to candy, especially chocolate. It may also be a play on "bunny". Her Japanese name comes from mimi, meaning ears.

name: Bones
saying:
A snack a day keeps the vacuum away.
Thanks for the snacks. Hint, hint.
犬、つちくれを逐う
description: Bones is a lazy, dog villager in the Animal Crossing series. He has appeared in every game up to date. His name is derived from bones, a popular treat for dogs, and possibly from the term "Lazy Bones." His catchphrase is probably from the noise dogs make.

name: Boomer
saying: Flying is believing.
description: Boomer is a lazy penguin villager who first appears in Animal Crossing as a islander. He is absent in Animal Crossing: Wild World, but reappears in later games. His name may come from the sound a bomb makes, boom. This is a reference to his appearance, which resembles a pilot. His Japanese catchphrase is also an onomatopoeia for a firing sound, further referencing his appearance.

name: Boone
saying:
Never settle for second best.
Words to live by: Don't ever wimp out!
description: Boone is a jock, gorilla villager in the Animal Crossing series first introduced in Animal Crossing: Wild World. Due to his personality, he appears competitive and active around the town. Both his English name and initial catchphrase - "baboom" - are likely allusions to the word baboon. Mantarou likely derives from マンドリル mandoriru (mandrill).

name: Boots
saying:
Strength lies in muscles.
上腕二頭筋
肱二头肌
description: Boots is a jock alligator villager from the Animal Crossing series, appearing in every game up until Doubutsu no Mori e+, then remaining absent until Animal Crossing: New Leaf - Welcome amiibo and Animal Crossing: Pocket Camp. Boots's name is derived from boots as footwear, because they can be made from tough alligator hide. His catchphrase, munchie, relates to "munching", an onomatopoeia for a chomping sound. Although not popular in his original Japanese origin, Boots's offbeat expressions and jock personality make him extremely popular to western gamers. Nintendo of America localizer Bill Trinen has also cited Boots as one of his most memorable villagers.

name: Boris
saying:
Life's short. Eat chocolate.
人生夢の如し
description: Boris is a cranky, pig villager that first appeared in Doubutsu no Mori, and would originally appear only in its GameCube ports until making a return in Animal Crossing: New Leaf - Welcome amiibo. His name presumably comes from the word "boar", an animal similar to a pig, and usually wild. His initial phrase, "schnort", is pronounced similarly to "snort", a noise pigs and boars make. Similarly, his Japanese catchphrase is the Japanese equivalent of this sound.

name: Boyd
saying: There's always time to take a second look.
description: Boyd is a cranky gorilla villager from the Animal Crossing series. He first appeared in Doubutsu no Mori e+, and returned in the Welcome amiibo update for Animal Crossing: New Leaf. Boyd's catchphrase may be derived from "ooh ooh", an onomanopoea in English for a primate sound. His Japanese catchphrase is the Japanese equivalent of this.

name: Bree
saying:
The gift says more about the giver.
Just in case you were wondering, I like presents.
山師の玄関
description: Bree is a snooty, mouse villager in the Animal Crossing series, appearing in every game of the Animal Crossing series since Doubutsu no Mori e+. Her name is likely derived from "brie", a type of French cheese, relating to the common stereotype that mice love cheese. Her catchphrase, "cheeseball", further relates to this.

name: Broccolo
saying:
One nap leads to another.
一芸は道に通ずる
description: Broccolo is a mouse villager with a lazy personality from the Animal Crossing series. Debuting in Doubutsu no Mori e+, he was absent from Animal Crossing: Wild World but returned to the Animal Crossing series in Animal Crossing: City Folk. His name and catchphrase, "eat it", are a possible reference to the vegetable broccoli, a vegetable that some children find undesirable. It may also relate to his lazy personality, whom are known to have a fondness of food.

name: Broffina
saying: Don't peck the hand that feeds you.
description: Broffina is a snooty chicken villager in the Animal Crossing series. She is a new character, first appearing in Animal Crossing: New Leaf. Her picture phrase is a reference to the popular saying, "Don't bite the hand that feeds you.", meaning to not act ungrateful to someone that you are dependent on.

name: Bruce
saying: Nobody's perfect.
description: Bruce is a cranky deer villager in the Animal Crossing series who debuted on Animal Crossing: New Leaf. His catchphrase is probably a reference to the fairy tale, "The Three Billy Goats Gruff", and is also the name of another cranky villager. The name "Bruce" may be derived from "bruise", a type of injury, which may reference the "tough" nature of cranky villagers. His name could also be a reference to the original Norwegian name of the goats in The Three Billy Goats Gruff, which is Bruse.

name: Bubbles
saying:
It's best to keep your lips and purse sealed.
口と財布は締めるが得
description: Bubbles is a peppy, hippo villager in the Animal Crossing series. Her name is derived from the fact that hippos live close to water, blowing bubbles when breathing underwater. It may also be a reference to "bubbly", reflecting her nature as a peppy villager.

name: Buck
saying:
Keep your eyes on the prize.
What are you staring at?!
弱り目にたたり目
description: Buck is a jock horse villager in the Animal Crossing series. As a jock villager, he will appear friendly and competitive when around the player. His name may refer to a vaulting horse used in gymnastics - which also gets the name from a type of horse sport where a rider tries to stay on top of a horse while it is "bucking." His initial phrase is a play on the word "partner", which is pronounced "pardner" by cowboys.

name: Bud
saying:
You're not living unless you're sweating!
明日は明日の風が吹く
description: Bud is a jock lion villager in the Animal Crossing series, who appears in all Animal Crossing series games except for the very first installment, Doubutsu no Mori. His Japanese name is a pun on the slang word gurasan, derived from sangurasu meaning sunglasses. From his debut in Animal Crossing to Doubutsu no Mori e+, he is an islander.

name: Bunnie
saying:
Hare today, gone tomorrow.
Come on! Get amped!
description: Bunnie is a peppy rabbit villager from the Animal Crossing series. She has been in all of the Animal Crossing games. Her name is derived from "bunny", an alternative, childish name for a rabbit. Her Japanese name may refer to knitting spools (commonly known as ririyan (Lily yarn) in Japan) which often come in a rabbit-like "Y" shape. She appears on the back of the case of the Animal Crossing: City Folk right by the 'Meet the neighbors' paragraph.

name: Butch
saying:
A house without either a cat or a dog is a sad house indeed.
I'm watching you!
寝るも忠義
description: Butch is a cranky, dog villager in the Animal Crossing series. His name reflects on the cartoon name given to dogs, usually meaning muscular in appearance. His Rottweiler appearance may also relate to this, as they too appear masculine and muscular. His initial phrase, "ROOOOOWF", is an amalgam of "woof" and "ruff". He is also the only dog with a cranky personality in all games except Doubutsu no Mori e+, where Champagne appears as well. He shares his Wild World picture quote with Curt, another villager.

name: Buzz
saying:
Pride'll put you in a pickle.
自慢は知恵の行き止まり
description: Buzz is an eagle villager with a cranky personality from the Animal Crossing series. His name comes from a buzzard, another type of bird of prey. Despite this, he resembles a golden eagle. Moreover, his Japanese phrase is a Japanese onomatopoeia for the sound a hawk makes.

name: Cally
saying:
It's always teatime somewhere.
縁は異なもの味なもの
description: Cally is a normal squirrel who appeared in Animal Crossing under the name Sally. Cally was absent in Animal Crossing: Wild World and Animal Crossing: City Folk, and then reappeared in Animal Crossing: New Leaf under the name Cally. Her name was used for another villager in Animal Crossing called Hazel, who is now called Sally since Animal Crossing: Wild World.

name: Camofrog
saying:
What you can't see can't hurt you.
You can't see me.
description: Camofrog is a cranky frog villager who has appeared in most Animal Crossing series games. His name relates to his appearance - a camouflaged frog. His initial phrase, "ten-hut", is an army term meaning "Come to attention"; this also relates to his appearance, as camouflage is frequently used in the army. His Wild World favorite saying, "You can't see me.", also comes from his camouflaged appearance. It is also a reference to former wrestler John Cena, who uses the quote as his catchphrase.

name: Canberra
saying: It's never too late to start over.
description: Canberra is a sisterly, koala villager in the Animal Crossing series. She first appeared in Animal Crossing: New Leaf. Her name most likely references the capital of Australia, Canberra, as Australia is the homeland of koalas.

name: Candi
saying:
The players may change, but the music stays the same.
演奏者が変われど音楽は変わらず
description: Candi is a peppy mouse villager in the Animal Crossing series. Following her debut in Doubutsu no Mori, Candi would appear in every game up until Doubutsu no Mori e+, in which she would remain absent until Animal Crossing: New Leaf - Welcome amiibo. Candi's name is derived from “candy”, a sugary food that many members of her personality, peppy, are known to overeat, making them hyper due to the excess sugar.

name: Carmen
saying:
Absence makes the heart grow fonder.
ケセラセラ
description: Carmen is a peppy rabbit villager who was introduced in Animal Crossing: City Folk. Her name was used in previous versions of the game for a snooty mouse.

name: Caroline
saying:
New brooms sweep clean.
Relax!
description: Caroline is a normal, squirrel villager from the Animal Crossing series. Originally appearing in Animal Crossing as an islander named Bliss, her English name was changed to Caroline in Animal Crossing: Wild World, which was her Japanese name.

name: Carrie
saying:
A mother's work is never done.
母の思いは子、子の思いは遊び
description: Carrie is a normal, kangaroo villager from the Animal Crossing series. After Doubutsu no Mori e+ was released, Carrie would be absent from any Animal Crossing series media until she reappeared in Animal Crossing: Happy Home Designer as one of the mandatory clients in the game, alongside Goldie and Lopez. Carrie made her reappearance in a mainline game in the Animal Crossing series in Animal Crossing: New Leaf - Welcome amiibo, followed by another appearance in Animal Crossing: Pocket Camp. Her name may possibly be derived from how female kangaroos carry their joeys. Her initial catchphrase, "little one", refers to her joey.

name: Cashmere
saying: 100% Wool
description: Cashmere is a snooty sheep villager from the Animal Crossing series. Having not appeared after Doubutsu no Mori e+, she eventually returned in Animal Crossing: New Leaf - Welcome amiibo.

name: Celia
saying: It's the thought that counts.
description: Celia is a normal eagle villager in the Animal Crossing series, first appearing in Animal Crossing: New Leaf. Celia is, most notably, the first female eagle villager since Amelia, who was the only female eagle for over a decade, prior to Celia's inclusion in Animal Crossing: New Leaf. She shares her Japanese name with Tiffany, another villager.

name: Cesar
saying:
As soon as you can grow a moustache, do it.
All hail my moustache!
人には髭があり、樹には根がある
description: Cesar is a large, orange gorilla with a cranky personality and black facial hair.  He has appeared in every Animal Crossing series game so far. His English name is an allusion to the Roman dictator Julius Caesar, hence the catchphrase "highness", which reflects his sense of self-importance and kingly status. He had a minor role in Doubutsu no Mori (film), where he was friends with Cyrano the anteater, another cranky villager.

name: Chadder
saying: Meeting is just the start of us saying good-bye.
description: Chadder is a smug mouse villager in the Animal Crossing series, making his initial appearance in Animal Crossing: New Leaf. His name is a distortion of cheddar, a kind of cheese. His initial phrase, "fromage", means "cheese" in French.

name: Charlise
saying: Actions speak louder than words.
description: Charlise is a sisterly bear villager from the Animal Crossing series. She first appeared in Doubutsu no Mori e+ as a peppy islander, then re-appeared in Animal Crossing: New Leaf as a sisterly villager.  Her name comes from a French/Portuguese word, charme, which translates to charm, a reference to her original Japanese name.

name: Cheri
saying:
Good things come in small packages.
山椒は小粒でもピリリと辛い
description: Not to be confused with Cherry.

name: Cherry
saying:
One dog barks at something; the rest bark at him.
番茶も出花
description: Not to be confused with Cheri.

name: Chester
saying: Sleep early. Wake late.
description: Chester is a lazy, cub villager in the Animal Crossing series, though he resembles a panda. Thus far, he has appeared in Animal Crossing: City Folk and Animal Crossing: New Leaf.

name: Chevre
saying:
If you're gonna dream, dream big.
Dream a little dream.
description: Chevre is a normal goat villager who has appeared in every game in the Animal Crossing series. The name "Chèvre" means goat in French, which matches her initial catchphrase "la baa", a play on the French phrase là bas (which means "over there") and the sound a goat makes, "baa".

name: Chief
saying:
Don't wish it was easier; wish you were better.
Harrumph!
人のふり見て我がふり直せ
description: Chief is a cranky, wolf villager, appearing in all games from the Animal Crossing series. As a cranky villager, he will appear grouchy and mean towards the player, but will slowly begin to warm up and befriend them.  His name may relate to his species, which live in packs lead by an alpha male, sometimes called a "chief". His initial phrase, "harrumph", is a sign of boredom or annoyance, often related to cranky villagers.

name: Chops
saying: You can't have your cake and eat it too.
description: Chops is a smug, pig villager in the Animal Crossing series who first appeared in Animal Crossing: New Leaf. His name comes from "pork chops," a food which is made from pigs. His Japanese name, Ton Fan, is a pun on ton, meaning "pork," and doufan the Japanese pronunciation of the former French noble title, dauphin, heir apparent to the throne.

name: Chow
saying:
All good things must come to an end.
Remember... I'm always watching you.
塵も積もれば山となる
description: Chow is a cranky bear villager from the Animal Crossing series. He has appeared in every game so far, with the exception of Animal Crossing: Pocket Camp. Chow's name comes from the spelling variation of the Chinese surname, Zhou - the fact that it is a Chinese (sur)name relates to Chow being a Panda Bear, which are native to China. In the city of Hull, England, "chow" is a colloquialism used for "telling off." As people are usually cranky when telling someone off, this relates to Chow's personality, although this is most likely a coincidence.

name: Chrissy
saying:
A fool and their Bells are soon parted.
姉の心、妹知らず
description: Chrissy is a peppy rabbit villager in the Animal Crossing series. She originally appeared in Doubutsu no Mori e+. She was absent in Animal Crossing: Wild World but returns in Animal Crossing: City Folk. According to the official Japanese Animal Crossing: City Folk website, she is the younger sister of Francine. This information is later confirmed to western players in Animal Crossing: Pocket Camp.

name: Claude
saying: Don't judge a rabbit by its ears.
description: Claude is a lazy rabbit villager from the Animal Crossing series, appearing in all games up to Doubutsu no Mori e+, and would remain absent until Animal Crossing: Happy Home Designer, in which Claude could be received through DLC alongside Louie, Maddie, Filly, and Felyne. His phrase, "hopalong", relates to the nature of rabbits to hop. His Japanese name is a reference to Vinegar, a cooking ingredient.

name: Claudia
saying: A tiger can't change its stripes.
description: Claudia is a snooty tiger villager in the Animal Crossing series who first appeared in Animal Crossing: New Leaf. Most notably, Claudia is the first female tiger since Bangle to appear in a Animal Crossing series title, which she shares with Bianca. Claudia's name is derived from a "claw", used to refer to the sharp nails of a tiger.

name: Clay
saying: Life is just a bowl of cherries.
description: Clay is a lazy hamster villager in the Animal Crossing series. He first appeared in Animal Crossing: New Leaf. His name is a reference to Dogū, a type of traditional Japanese clay figurine, which his appearance is based on.

name: Cleo
saying:
There's something lovable in all of us.
風呂ではみんな素っ裸
description: Cleo is a snooty, horse villager from the Animal Crossing series. She is named after Cleo Ridgely, a professional horseback rider and actress. Her catchphrase, sugar, refers to sugarcubes, a treat which horses enjoy eating. "Sugar" is also an affectionate nickname used by individuals in the American south, some of whom, especially females, act refined, posh, and chic. She appeared only in the GameCube games until she returned in Animal Crossing: New Leaf - Welcome amiibo.

name: Clyde
saying: The grass is always greener.
description: Clyde is a lazy horse villager who first appears in Animal Crossing: City Folk. His English and Japanese names may both be derived from Clydesdale, a horse breed. His catchphrase comes from the noise horses make with their hooves when walking on a hard surface, clip-clop.

name: Coach
saying: Fool me once, shame on you. Fool me twice, shame on me.
description: Coach is a jock bull villager in the Animal Crossing series. He first appeared in Animal Crossing: New Leaf. His name refers to sports coaches, relating to his jock personality. His catchphrase "stubble" relates to the five o'clock shadow he has which is commonly called a stubble. He is the only bull villager that is not lazy or cranky.

name: Cobb
saying: Might makes right.
description: Cobb is a jock pig villager from the Animal Crossing series. His name comes from corn on the cob, and pigs like to eat corn.  His Japanese name, "Hakase", means doctor, which refers to his appearance being similar to that of a stereotypical doctor.  His catchphrase refers to how pigs are used for hot dogs.

name: Coco
saying:
Don't put off till tomorrow what you can do today.
I'm feeling kind of blank today.
description: Coco is a normal rabbit villager from the Animal Crossing series. She has appeared in every game so far.

name: Cole
saying: Little pitchers have big ears.
description: Cole is a lazy rabbit villager who first appeared in Animal Crossing: New Leaf. His name is likely a play on "coal", relating to his black color. His Japanese name comes from the Amami rabbit.

name: Colton
saying: Make hay while the sun shines.
description: Colton is a smug, horse villager in the Animal Crossing series. He first appeared in Animal Crossing: New Leaf. His name Colton derives from the young male horse, a colt.

name: Cookie
saying:
Don't lose sight of what you're really after.
犬が西向きゃ尾は東
description: This article is about the villager. If you were looking for the cookies sold in Nook's shop, see Fortune Cookie. If you were looking for the cookies sold at the fireworks festival, see Redd's Cookie.

name: Cousteau
saying: Jump first; ask questions later.
description: Cousteau is a jock frog villager in the Animal Crossing series. He first appeared in Doubutsu no Mori, but was absent in Animal Crossing: Wild World and made a reappearance in Animal Crossing: City Folk. As a jock villager, he will be interested in sport and fitness, as well as appear hospitable and competitive towards the player.

name: Cranston
saying: Hard work beats talent.
description: Cranston is a lazy, ostrich villager in the Animal Crossing series. He first appeared in Animal Crossing: New Leaf. His name may come from "crane," which he resembles, while his initial catchphrase may cause one to confuse him for a jock villager.

name: Croque
saying: Where there's smoke, there's fire.
description: Croque is a cranky frog villager in the Animal Crossing series. He was introduced in Animal Crossing: New Leaf. His name derives from the onomatopoeia of the sound frogs make: “croak”, while his catchphrase highlights his cranky personality.

name: Cube
saying:
Sometimes you gotta learn to chill.
Stay cool.
description: Cube is a lazy, penguin villager in the Animal Crossing series who first appears in Animal Crossing. His English name is possibly taken from the Nintendo GameCube, the console in which he makes his first appearance on in the West, although he may alternatively be named after ice cubes.  His Japanese name, Vis, which is French for screw, is likely a reference to his unique screw-like eyes.

name: Curlos
saying:
If you want to know yourself better, ask your neighbors.
我が身の事は人に問え
description: Curlos is a sheep villager in the Animal Crossing series who made his first appearance in Doubutsu no Mori e+ as a cranky islander. He later returned in Animal Crossing: New Leaf as a villager, now under the smug personality.

name: Curly
saying: Get fired up!
description: Curly is a jock, pig villager from the Animal Crossing series. His name comes from his curly tail.  It is also possible his name is a reference to the Three Stooges, as his catchphrase is "nyoink", which could be based off Curly the Stooge's "nyuk nyuk nyuk" catchphrase.

name: Curt
saying:
A bell saved is a bell earned.
I'm watching you!
あきかんはくずかごに
description: Curt is a cranky bear villager in the Animal Crossing series. To be "curt" is to be impolitely brief, hence his personality, which are known to be brief and impolite. It also sounds similar to "hurt", referring to the bandage on Curt's head. He shares his picture quote with Butch, another villager.

name: Cyd
saying: Do what you want, but do it loud!
description: Cyd is a cranky elephant villager who first appeared in Animal Crossing: New Horizons.[1] His name is likely a reference to punk rock musician Sid Vicious, Sid being a potential homonym for Cyd, which fits with the references to punk and other punk acts in translation.

name: Cyrano
saying:
Don't cut off your nose to spite your face.
Wish you were here!
description: Cyrano is a cranky anteater villager that appears in all games from the Animal Crossing series. He is named after Cyrano de Bergerac, a French dramatist and duelist known, among other things, for his large nose. Cyrano's portrait quote may be a reference to a statue of his namesake in Bergerac, Dordogne, a commune in southern France. He appeared in Doubutsu no Mori (film) as a minor character, being friends with Cesar, the gorilla.

name: Daisy
saying:
It's not always a dog-eat-dog world.
Just a regular girl in a crazy world!
味は食べてみるまではわからない
description: Daisy is a normal dog villager from the Animal Crossing series. She has appeared in every game so far. Her catchphrase, 'bow-WOW,' is the noise that dogs make, with an emphasis on WOW to indicate interest, similar to the cat villager Tabby's catchphrase, 'me-WOW.'

name: Deena
saying:
Duck...duck...GOOSE!
I'm not a lame duck!
description: Deena is a normal duck villager appearing in all installments of the Animal Crossing series.

name: Deirdre
saying: Legs of an antelope, heart of an eagle.
description: Deirdre is a sisterly deer villager in the Animal Crossing series. Her name is of Irish origin, and is a pun on her species. She first appeared in Animal Crossing: New Leaf.

name: Del
saying: The hero is brave in deeds as well as words.
description: Del is a cranky alligator villager in the Animal Crossing series. Del first appeared in Doubutsu no Mori e+, and again in Animal Crossing: City Folk and Animal Crossing: New Leaf. Del's name is a shortened version of a river delta, a deposition of sediment left behind by a flowing river, which are sometimes occupied by alligators. His Japanese name refers to the Yamato people, or the battleship Yamato. His Japanese favorite saying is also similar to Sylvana's English favorite saying in Animal Crossing: New Leaf - Welcome amiibo.

name: Deli
saying: Righty tighty, lefty loosey.
description: Deli is a lazy, monkey villager in the Animal Crossing series. He first appeared in Animal Crossing: New Leaf. His name may be a  reference to New Delhi, the capital of India.

name: Derwin
saying: Everything in moderation. Except for snacks.
description: Derwin is a lazy, duck villager who has appeared in all games from the Animal Crossing series. He gained his glasses after an incident involving a soccer ball hitting him in the head and disorienting his vision, according to his e-Card bio.

name: Diana
saying: Sometimes you have to lose to win.
description: Diana is a snooty deer villager in the Animal Crossing series. She first appeared in Animal Crossing: New Leaf. Her English name refers to the mythical Diana, the Goddess of the Hunt, who transformed a huntsman into a deer when he glimpsed her bathing in the woods; in reference to this, her home is themed after a bathhouse. Her catchphrase "no doy" is a term used to label something as common knowledge in an informal conversation, relating to her snooty personality. "Doy" also sounds similar to "doe", a name for a female deer.

name: Diva
saying: Eyes are the windows to the soul.
description: Diva is a sisterly, frog villager in the Animal Crossing series. She first appeared in Animal Crossing: New Leaf. Her English name means a celebrated female singer in the world of opera, and nowadays by extension in theater, cinema and popular music.

name: Dizzy
saying: Keep it mellow.
description: Dizzy is a lazy elephant villager from the Animal Crossing series.

name: Dobie
saying: Old longings never truly fade
description: This article is about the wolf villager. For the chicken villager whose English name is the same as this villager's Japanese name, please see Ken.

name: Doc
saying: One cannot live on carrots alone.
description: Doc is a lazy, rabbit villager from the Animal Crossing series. He is named from the Bugs Bunny quote, "Eh, what's up doc?", as he is a rabbit. It may, however, simply relate to his appearance, which resembles a doctor or psychologist.

name: Dom
saying: Be true to your most shiny self.
description: Dom is a jock sheep villager who first appeared in Animal Crossing: New Horizons.

name: Dora
saying:
The squeaky wheel gets the cheese.
Got any cheese for me?
無い時の辛抱有る時の倹約
description: Dora is a normal mouse villager from the Animal Crossing series. Her catch phrase, "squeaky," is a reference to the sound that mice make. Her name may also be a reference to dormice. Her picture quote in Animal Crossing: New Leaf is a reference to the proverb "The squeaky wheel gets the grease."

name: Dotty
saying:
It's always a good hare day.
Hop to it, wee one!
description: Dotty is a peppy, rabbit villager in the Animal Crossing series. Her name relates to her large, circled eyes and area of her ears, though it could also be a reference to the word "dotty", which means "small", hence her catchphrase "wee one". "Dotty" can also mean "eccentric", and to be "dotty" about something means to like, love, or show a great interest in something or someone. Both of these fit with the airheaded, yet positive nature of peppy villagers.

name: Drago
saying: There is no room for two dragons in one pond.
description: Drago is a lazy alligator villager who first appears in Animal Crossing: New Leaf. His name means "dragon" in Italian. Similarly, his Japanese name, Tatsuo, is derived from tatsu (龍/竜), meaning "dragon", specifically Asian dragons (Western dragons are referred to in katakana as doragon (ドラゴン)).

name: Drake
saying:
...Quack.
Got any snacks on you?
description: Drake is a lazy duck villager from the Animal Crossing series, appearing in every game since Animal Crossing: Wild World. The name "Drake" comes from the word given to male ducks. His initial phrase, "quacko", is play on the word "quack", the sound ducks make. Likewise, His Japanese phrase, kamo ne, is a He shares this catchphrase with Bill, another male duck; and shares his Wild World picture quote with Elmer, another lazy villager.

name: Drift
saying: Always go for the gold!
description: Drift is a jock, frog villager in the Animal Crossing series. In Animal Crossing, he appeared as an islander. His name may come from his original role as an islander and his catchphrase comes from the sound a frog makes combined with "bro", a term that jocks commonly use in conversations. His Japanese catchphrase is the sound of a frog's croaking in Japanese.

name: Ed
saying:
Beauty is pain!
美しさを得たければ傷を受けよ
description: Ed is a horse villager who first appeared in Doubutsu no Mori as a jock villager, but was given a smug personality in Animal Crossing: New Leaf. He has appeared in most of the games in the Animal Crossing series, with the exceptions of Wild World and Pocket Camp. His name may come from Mr. Ed, a television show about a talking horse that aired in the early 1960s. His initial phrase, greenhorn, is a slang word to refer to amateurs, relating to both his original jock personality and his current smug personality.

name: Egbert
saying:
You gotta break a few eggs to make an omelet.
Napping is when I do my best thinking.
多くを知る人は多く苦しむ
description: Egbert is a lazy, chicken villager in the Animal Crossing series who has appeared in every game to date. His name is a combination of egg, the thing his species lays; and the name "Bert," a surname of "Robert." His Japanese name can mean "chilblains" or "frostbite." Egbert's favorite saying in Animal Crossing: New Leaf, which is "You gotta break a few eggs to make an omelet," means that you cannot have success without loss.

name: Elise
saying:
Do as I say, not as I do.
If you say anything stupid about bananas or monkeying around, I'll scream!
description: Elise is a snooty, monkey villager from the Animal Crossing series. She, along with all other monkeys, was new in Animal Crossing: Wild World. Her initial phrase "puh-lease" relates to the snooty personality.

name: Ellie
saying:
You need the sour to highlight the sweet.
酸いも甘いも噛み分ける
description: Ellie is a normal, elephant villager from the Animal Crossing series. She first appeared in Doubutsu no Mori. Following more than a decade of absence, she made a reappearance in Animal Crossing: New Leaf - Welcome amiibo. Her name comes from the first part of the word elephant. Ellie's catchphrase "wee one" is shared with Dotty in Animal Crossing. In Animal Crossing: New Leaf - Welcome amiibo, this was changed to "lil one" to avoid confusion.

name: Elmer
saying:
The horse doesn't pull the cart, the oats do.
Got any snacks on you?
馬も買わずに鞍買う
description: Elmer is a lazy horse villager. He appears in all games from the Animal Crossing series. His name could be a reference to either  the Elmer Horse Collection, a company which makes horse figurines, or Elmer Glue (glue used to be made from horses). His initial phrase, "tenderfoot", may relate to the cowboy ranch rank, where a tenderfoot is an inexperienced ranchman, or "cowboy". This may also be related to one of the Boy Scout ranks in American Scouts. His picture quote is referring to his lazy personality, because lazy villagers enjoy the consumption of food. He shares his picture quote with Drake, another villager.

name: Eloise
saying:
An elephant never forgets.
You'll want to display this prominently!
終わり良ければすべて良し
description: Eloise is a snooty elephant villager in the Animal Crossing series. She has appeared in every Animal Crossing series game to date. Her name is derived from the first part of "elephant," her species, and the French given name "Éloïse."

name: Elvis
saying:
Better a live coward than a dead hero.
Thank you very much.
description: Elvis is a cranky, lion villager from the Animal Crossing series. His catchphrase and picture quote are references to Elvis Presley, the famous singer. Presley was also known as "the King" - a reference that lends itself to the lion, which is known in popular culture as "the king of the jungle." His initial shirt and his house are references to a king also.

name: Erik
saying: If you're afraid of wolves, don't go to the woods.
description: Erik is a lazy, deer villager in the Animal Crossing series. He first appeared in Animal Crossing: New Leaf. His English name most likely comes from elk, a large species of deer.

name: Eugene
saying: Imitation is the sincerest form of flattery.
description: Eugene is a smug koala villager who was introduced in Animal Crossing: New Leaf. His name is a reference to the eucalyptus plant, which koalas eat the leaves of. His Japanese name likely refers to his "rocky" style.

name: Eunice
saying: There is a point to every encounter.
description: Eunice is a sheep villager with a normal personality. She first appeared in Animal Crossing, but was absent in Animal Crossing: Wild World. She returns to the Animal Crossing series in Animal Crossing: City Folk. Her name is derived from "ewe", used to refer to a female sheep. Her Japanese name comes from Mohair, a specific type of fabric made from Angora goat hair.  Her catchphrase comes from the byproduct of young sheep, a lamb, called a lamb chop.

name: Fang
saying:
You mess with the wolf, you get the fangs.
真っ黒より灰色の方がまし
description: Fang is a cranky, wolf villager in the Animal Crossing series. He did not appear in Animal Crossing: Wild World, but reappeared in Animal Crossing: City Folk. His name comes from the fang, a tooth found in carnivores.  It may also be a reference to the 1906 Jack London novel White Fang. His Japanese name is named after Siberia, a region in northern Asia that is mostly an arctic environment.

name: Fauna
saying: The first step is always the hardest.
description: Fauna is a normal deer villager in the Animal Crossing series. She is a new character in Animal Crossing: New Leaf and is one of the first villagers announced for the release of the game. Her name is a pun on 'fawn', meaning a young deer, and 'fauna', a term used for animals of a specific time or place. More specifically, it may be a reference to mythical fauns, which are half-goat, half human creatures in Roman mythology heavily associated with 'wildness'. Her initial catchphrase is a pun on "deer". Similarly, her Japanese catchphrase is a pun on desu ka, a question sentence ending, and shika, meaning deer.

name: Felicity
saying:
Love has no bounds.
恋に上下の隔てなし
description: Felicity is a peppy cat villager in the Animal Crossing series who first appeared in Doubutsu no Mori e+. Her name is derived from "feline," a scientific adjective for cats, and is also an uncommon given name. She was absent in Animal Crossing: Wild World, but returned in Animal Crossing: City Folk.

name: Filbert
saying:
Don't go nuts or anything.
赤子のから笑い
description: Filbert is a lazy squirrel villager, who appears in every installment of Animal Crossing series. His name, like most of his species, came from a type of nut. In this case, his name comes from the species of hazelnut. His Japanese name is the same as the English name of another squirrel, Ricky.

name: Flip
saying: See no donut, hear no donut, speak no donut.
description: Flip is a monkey villager in the Animal Crossing series. He first appeared in Animal Crossing: New Leaf, where he  replaces Champ who was originally intended to appear. Flip's name is likely a reference to a monkey's behavior: some monkeys are known to flip in the air while climbing in trees, and his picture quote is a reference to "see no evil, hear no evil, say no evil", otherwise known as the "three evils" that is typically represented by three monkeys. His Japanese name refers to Sarutobi Sasuke, a famous fictional ninja whose surname Sarutobi means "monkey jump".

name: Flo
saying: Always keep a straight face.
description: Flo is a sisterly penguin villager in the Animal Crossing series. She first appeared in Animal Crossing: New Leaf. Her Japanese name is the same as Leila's English name. Her name likely comes from "ice floe", referencing penguins' icy habitat. Her Japanese name is a pun on rei, meaning cold.

name: Flora
saying: Pink is the new black.
description: Flora is a peppy, ostrich villager in the Animal Crossing series that first appeared in Animal Crossing: New Leaf. She borrows Nana's picture quote in Animal Crossing: Wild World, although Flora's has a period instead of an exclamation mark. Her catchphrase is also the name of another peppy villager, Pinky.

name: Flurry
saying: Squeak your mind, even if your voice shakes.
description: Flurry is a normal hamster villager in the Animal Crossing series. She first appeared in Animal Crossing: New Leaf. Her English name refers to a flurry of snow, or a light, brief snow shower. Fittingly, Flurry was later added to Animal Crossing: Pocket Camp to promote the winter theme as a result, alongside Fang, Aurora, Diana, and Bianca.

name: Francine
saying: You can't have wise folks if you don't have fools too.
description: Francine is a snooty, rabbit villager in the Animal Crossing series. Her initial phrase "karat" is a homophone on the vegetable, carrot - a typical food item for rabbits and carat in the UK, - a way to measure gold purity. As a snooty villager, gold would possibly refer to her stylish, materialistic lifestyle. She is the older sister of Chrissy.

name: Frank
saying: Today is the last day of the rest of your life.
description: Frank is a cranky, eagle villager from the Animal Crossing series, who first appeared as an islander in Doubutsu no Mori e+. Frank's name could be a reference to his cranky personality: To be “frank” is to be impolitely brief and to the point, sometimes coming across as insulting. Frank's name is also the Japanese name of another eagle villager.

name: Freckles
saying:
Act now before you change your mind!"
"CATAPULTING CUPCAKES!
description: Freckles is a peppy duck villager from the Animal Crossing series. She has appeared in every game in the series to date.

name: Freya
saying:
Don't stray too far from the pack.
香りは人を酔わせる
description: Freya is a snooty wolf villager, who appears in all games from the Animal Crossing series except Wild World. Her name derives from the Norse goddess of beauty, Freyja. Her catchphrase, "uff da," is a Norwegian exclamation that translates to "I am overwhelmed." Her Japanese name is derived from “tundra”, a region of arctic wasteland commonly inhabited by wolves.

name: Friga
saying:
You can't learn a life lesson from a fortune cookie.
This isn't a fortune cookie, it's an important life lesson!
一夜の氷の上を歩くな
description: Friga is a snooty, penguin villager in the Animal Crossing series. She has appeared in every game so far. Friga may be named from "frigid," meaning cold, which relates to many typical penguins being Antarctic creatures. "Frigid" also means "stiff" or "formal", words which befit the overly formal lifestyles of snooty villagers.

name: Frita
saying: Don't sweat the small potatoes.
description: Frita is a sisterly, sheep villager in the Animal Crossing series. She first appeared in Animal Crossing: New Leaf. Her name comes from fritas, meaning "fries" in Portuguese. Her Japanese name is the same as the English name of Wendy, another sheep villager.

name: Frobert
saying:
Always aim high!
I don't wanna see any lily-livered jumping! Always aim high!
description: Frobert is a jock, frog villager in the Animal Crossing series. His name is a portmanteau of the name "Robert" and the word "frog". His initial phrase is a play on the word "ribbit", the sound a frog makes. He was originally in Doubutsu no Mori e+, and later in Animal Crossing: Wild World and Animal Crossing: City Folk.

name: Fuchsia
saying: It takes one to know one.
description: Fuchsia is a sisterly deer villager in the Animal Crossing series. She first appeared in Animal Crossing: New Leaf. Her name derives from the color of her fur, a shade of pink referred to as fuchsia. Fuchsia also appears on the cover of K.K. Disco.

name: Gabi
saying:
The more the merrier.
I'm trying out a new earstyle here.
description: Gabi is a rabbit villager with a peppy personality who has appeared in all Animal Crossing series titles so far. Her Japanese name is from a Russian style of stove used for cooking and home heating. Her catchphrase relates to her species, "bun" being a shortening of "bunny." She appears on the cover of Animal Crossing: amiibo Festival, standing in front of the Town Tree, where she is hosting the Board Game mode. In Animal Crossing: Happy Home Designer, her request is "A room with a piano," which is a reference to the composer and pianist Ludwig van Beethoven, who shares a birthday with Gabi. Her name is also the Japanese name of a cranky cub villager.

name: Gala
saying: Still waters run deep.
description: Gala is a normal villager in the Animal Crossing series, who makes her first appearance in Animal Crossing: City Folk. Her name may refer to Gala Apples.

name: Gaston
saying:
An ear for an ear leaves everyone deaf.
Sacre bleu!
description: Gaston is a cranky rabbit villager in the Animal Crossing series. His initial phrase and name suggest he is French, or from French origin. His name, Gaston, is a male French name and his initial phrase, "mon chou", is a play on words with "chou chou", a term of endearment. "Mon chou" on its own translates to "my cabbage". Gaston's photo inscription reads as "Sacre Bleu!", further establishing his character as a Frenchman.

name: Gayle
saying: An ounce of prevention is worth a pound of cure.
description: Gayle is a normal alligator villager in the Animal Crossing series. She first appeared in Animal Crossing: New Leaf. Her name may derive from "scale", a jagged area of skin typically seen on reptiles including alligators, or it may simply be from "gator". Her Japanese name is the word "alligator" combined with "Betty". It also sounds similar to "arigatou," Japanese for "thank you," reflecting Gayle's normal personality, which are often seen to be overly grateful.

name: Genji
saying:
Fall down seven times, get up eight.
Hai-ya!
春なれや　名もなき山の　薄霞
description: Genji is a rabbit villager in the Animal Crossing series. He has a jock personality, which means he will appear competitive towards the player. His name could refer to two things. "Genji" means a "military geek" in Japanese, and "Genji" is also the titular character in The Tale of Genji by Murasaki Shikibu, which is often considered to be the world's first novel. His initial phrase, "mochi", is a type of Japanese rice cake made with rice flour pounded into paste; Genji himself somewhat resembles mochi. His phrase prior to New Horizons was "otaku", which means, in Japanese, someone with an obsessive personality, reflecting on the jock villagers' fitness and health obsession. He is best friends with Aziz, according to his e-Card bio.

name: Gigi
saying: Look at the world through rose-colored glasses.
description: Gigi is a snooty frog villager from the Animal Crossing series. Her first appearance was in Animal Crossing: City Folk. Her catchphrase is a combination of the sound a frog makes, and the French suffix "-ette," which is feminine.

name: Gladys
saying:
Smiles are free.
Smiles are free, you know.
歩く姿は百合の花
description: Gladys is a normal, ostrich villager in the Animal Crossing series. Her appearance seems to be based on the Red-crowned Crane. Her name is based around her personality; a neutral name that is unlike the other personality type villagers, which all have names relating to their species and character. Her initial phrase, "stretch", is a joke on her species, which are known to have long legs.

name: Gloria
saying: Time is money.
description: Gloria is a snooty, duck villager in the Animal Crossing series who made her first appearance in Animal Crossing: City Folk. Her catchphrase is "quacker", a play on the noise ducks make. Her English and Japanese name both refer to silent film actress Gloria Swanson.

name: Goldie
saying:
A little bit of happiness is better than a lot of anguish.
I'm really into that Lab on the cover of Nintendogs. He's pretty dreamy.
中位の幸せが一番よい
description: Goldie is a normal dog villager, appearing in every game in the Animal Crossing series to date. Her name is based on the breed of dog she is, a Golden Retriever, with the "Golden" being turned into the name "Goldie."  Her catchphrase is a popular way to interpret the sound dogs make, and her Japanese catchphrase, wan, is the Japanese equivalent. In Animal Crossing: Happy Home Designer, she is one of the three mandatory clients in the game, the others being Lopez and Carrie.

name: Gonzo
saying:
Brothers are brothers, cheese is cheese.
兄弟は兄弟、チーズはチーズ
description: Gonzo, the cranky koala, is a villager from the Animal Crossing series. His initial phrase, "mate," is a common way for an Australian to refer to a friend. He originally appeared in the original games up to Doubutsu no Mori e+, although he was planned to appear in Animal Crossing: Happy Home Designer but was cut. He eventually returned in Animal Crossing: New Leaf - Welcome amiibo as an amiibo card villager.

name: Goose
saying:
Birds of a feather crow together.
Who ya callin' chicken, chicken?!
早起きは三ベルの得
description: Goose is a jock chicken villager in the Animal Crossing series who has appeared in every game so far. His name is a reference to the bird, a goose, though his actual species is a chicken. His Japanese name likely comes from Kentucky, in reference to Kentucky Fried Chicken. His initial phrase, "buh-kay," is a play on the word "okay" and the sound a chicken makes.

name: Graham
saying: Knowledge is power.
description: Graham is a smug, hamster villager in the Animal Crossing series. He first appears in Animal Crossing: New Leaf. His name could be based on "glasses" (his appearance), which is グラス (gurasu) in Japanese, "hamster" (his species), and the name "Graham."

name: Greta
saying: The world is a stage.
description: Greta is a snooty, mouse villager in the Animal Crossing series who first appeared in Animal Crossing: New Leaf. Greta's design is based on the otafuku, a type of Japanese mask. Her name was originally a derivation of the female given name Margareta, becoming later a proper name and thus maintaining its meaning, "pearl" - befitting the trend to associate snooty villagers with rare gems or glamorous things.

name: Grizzly
saying: Those who live in glass houses shouldn't throw stones.
description: Grizzly is a cranky bear villager in the Animal Crossing series. The name "Grizzly" refers to his nature and the grizzly bear, though he more closely resembles a black bear. Grizzly was absent from Animal Crossing: Wild World, but he reappears in Animal Crossing: City Folk.

name: Groucho
saying:
Rocky road is more than just a flavor of ice cream.
若いときの苦労は買うてもせよ
description: Groucho is a cranky, bear villager in the Animal Crossing series, first appearing in Animal Crossing. He was absent in Animal Crossing: Wild World, but returned to the Animal Crossing series in Animal Crossing: City Folk. His name may come from the word "grouchy," another word used for someone who is "cranky." In real life, a famous Groucho was the middle brother of five, who went on to form The Marx Brothers; another of the brothers' names appears in the Animal Crossing series, named Chico the mouse.

name: Gruff
saying: Don't burn bridges.
description: Gruff is a cranky, goat villager in the Animal Crossing series. His name comes from the Norwegian fairytale, The Three Billy Goats Gruff, while his Japanese name is simply from "billy goat," which is shared with Billy, another goat villager. His picture quote, "Don't burn bridges," means to not leave your past behind; to "burn your bridges" means to set up your past in a way that you can never return to it.

name: Gwen
saying:
Mind your manners, or someone else will.
I'm just that cool.
description: Gwen is a snooty penguin villager in the Animal Crossing series. Gwen's name is a play on Penguin. Her Japanese name, Pōra, is the way both "Paula" and "polar" are pronounced in Japanese, referencing the cold climates associated with penguins.

name: Hamlet
saying: The ear's the thing.
description: Hamlet is a jock, hamster villager in the Animal Crossing series. He first appears in Animal Crossing: New Leaf. His name refers to his appearance as a small hamster, and is named after the Shakespeare character of the same name. His picture quote is an allusion to Prince Hamlet's quote, "The play's the thing." Hamlet's Japanese name is a portmanteau of "Hamster" and -suke, a common Japanese boys' name suffix.

name: Hamphrey
saying: Children should be seen and not heard.
description: Hamphrey is a cranky hamster villager in the Animal Crossing series. His name may be a combination of "Hamster" and the common name "Humphrey". He first appeared in Animal Crossing: New Leaf.

name: Hans
saying: One good turn deserves another.
description: Hans is a smug, gorilla villager in the Animal Crossing series that debuted in Animal Crossing: New Leaf. He strikingly resembles a yeti, which is made more apparent by his phrase and name. His initial phrase "groovy" is possibly a pun relating to being cool. The name Hans is a popular masculine name in Scandinavian countries, places characterized by cold temperatures and mountains. Sunairu likely derives from スノー sunō (snow) and ゴリラ gorira (gorilla). His favorite saying is similar to that of Rosie, except "purr" is replaced by "turn."

name: Harry
saying: Patience is a virtue for folks with time.
description: Harry is a hippo villager in the Animal Crossing series. He first appeared in Doubutsu no Mori e+ as an islander under the jock personality, then later reappeared in Animal Crossing: City Folk as a cranky villager, after being absent in Animal Crossing: Wild World. He, alongside Violet, is the second villager to have his personality changed. His name may be a play on the word "hairy," which refers to his beard. His initial phrase, "beach bum," possibly references the fact that he was an islander in e+.

name: Hazel
saying: Never say never!
description: Hazel is a sisterly, squirrel villager in the Animal Crossing series. She was debuted in Animal Crossing: New Leaf. Her name is most likely derived from the color of her fur and from hazelnuts. Her name also originally belonged to Sally.

name: Henry
saying: The way to a frog's heart is through his stomach.
description: Henry is a smug, frog villager in the Animal Crossing series. He first appeared in Animal Crossing: New Leaf. His name is most likely a reference to the frog prince's servant Henry in the fairy tale The Frog Prince.

name: Hippeux
saying: Mottoes are for the unoriginal.
description: Hippeux is a smug, hippo villager in the Animal Crossing series. He first appeared in Animal Crossing: New Leaf. His name is intended to be pronounced like a French name, so out loud, it is pronounced identically to his species name. According to Animal Crossing: Pocket Camp, his real name is Gary.

name: Hopkins
saying:
A wise man gives danger a wide berth.
君子危うきに近寄らず
description: Hopkins is a lazy rabbit villager from the Animal Crossing series, first appearing in the Japanese exclusive Doubutsu no Mori e+. Like other villagers from this game, he also appears in Animal Crossing: New Leaf - Welcome amiibo as one of the first new characters unveiled. Hopkins' name is derived from "hopping", a common behavior of rabbits, while his catchphrase is a reference to the Bambi character of the same name, who is also a rabbit.

name: Hopper
saying:
Always have a comeback.
This is my good side.
七転び八起き
description: Hopper is a cranky penguin villager in the Animal Crossing series who is named after the rockhopper penguin, although he more closely resembles a Macaroni Penguin. In Japanese, however, Hopper is likely named after Bodhidharma, better known in Japan as "Daruma," the founder of Zen Buddhism and the inspiration for the Daruma Dolls. In addition to appearing in every game of the series (with the exception of Animal Crossing: Pocket Camp), Hopper also appeared in Doubutsu no Mori (film) with a minor role.

name: Hornsby
saying: You can't hit a mosquito with a horseshoe.
description: Hornsby is a lazy, rhino villager from the Animal Crossing series. His name is a play on the horn on his head. Although his files from Animal Crossing: Happy Home Designer can be found, Hornsby is absent from that game.

name: Huck
saying: Cold coffee makes for a cold demeanor.のど元過ぎても口は熱い
description: Huck is a frog villager from the Animal Crossing series. In Doubutsu no Mori and Animal Crossing, he was a lazy villager. He was then absent from the games up until the Animal Crossing: New Leaf - Welcome amiibo update, where he returned with a smug personality.

name: Hugh
saying:
Keep it real. Real chill.
眠りは甘く、仕事は苦い
description: Hugh is a lazy, pig villager in the Animal Crossing series. He has appeared in every game to date. Hugh's name may be derived from "blue", which may refer to Hugh's coloring.

name: Iggly
saying: Six of one, half dozen of the other.
description: Iggly is a jock, penguin villager. As a jock villager, he will appear friendly and competitive towards the player. His name is based on the word "igloo," and his catchphrase is based on "waddling," the way penguins walk. His debut was in Animal Crossing: City Folk.

name: Ike
saying:
The higher you climb, the smaller things look.
木の上に立って見る
description: Ike is a cranky bear villager that first appeared in Doubutsu no Mori e+, and later returned in the Animal Crossing: New Leaf Welcome amiibo update. According to his e-card bio, he is Poko's father.

name: Jacob
saying:
Your greatest strength can be your greatest weakness.
薫は香を以て自ら焼く
description: Jacob, known as Jakey in PAL regions, is a lazy bird villager in the Animal Crossing series. He first appeared in Doubutsu no Mori e+, after which he didn't reappear until Animal Crossing: New Leaf's Welcome amiibo Update.

name: Jacques
saying: Better to have loved and squawked than to have never loved at all.
description: Jacques is a smug, bird villager in the Animal Crossing series. He first appeared in Animal Crossing: New Leaf. His name comes from the word Disk Jockey, or DJ, for short. His English name may also come from Jacques Cousteau, an oceanographer who also wore a beanie. His catchphrase is French for "darn it," referencing his name, the French counterpart for Jack.

name: Jambette
saying:
It takes more muscles to frown than to smile.
追いかけキスはしないもの
description: Jambette is a normal, frog villager in the Animal Crossing series, appearing in nearly every game except for Animal Crossing: Wild World and Animal Crossing: Pocket Camp. As a normal villager, she will appear hospitable towards the player and be easy to befriend. Jambette is a French name meaning "leggy," a reference to the stereotype that the French love to eat frog legs. Despite her name, Jambette's most recognizable feature is her bright pink lipstick, which gives the impression that she is a snooty villager instead of a normal villager. Her initial catchphrase is a play on words, combining the words "croak" and "okay."

name: Jay
saying:
He who hesitates has lost!
You gotta want it!
description: Jay is a jock, bird villager in the Animal Crossing series. His English name is derived from the species of bird of the same name, although there are no jays that have red heads like the villager. His Japanese name is the katakana writing of the kanji 燕 (Tsubakuro), "Swallow" (the species of bird). Also, his forked tail, red head, blue body, and white belly also suggests a barn swallow. His Japanese name is also derived from "comfort" or "enjoy".

name: Jeremiah
saying:
Sleep before you leap.
Think about it, man. Bullfrog is only one letter away from blue frog.
蛙のいない池の水は良くない
description: Jeremiah is a lazy, frog villager in the Animal Crossing series. His name is most likely a reference to the 1971 rock song "Joy to the World" by Three Dog Night, known for its opening line "Jeremiah was a bullfrog".

name: Jitters
saying: When you're a team of one, you're always captain!
description: Jitters is a jock bird villager from the Animal Crossing series, who made his debut in Animal Crossing: Wild World. His name can refer to nervousness, perhaps due to his small pupils making him appear nervous or stressed out.

name: Joey
saying: Don't get your feathers all ruffled. Just chill.
description: Joey is a duck villager in the Animal Crossing series with a lazy personality. His name may be a reference to Joey Tribbiani, a character from the American sitcom, Friends, who is also quite lazy and fond of food.

name: Judy
saying: I'm dancing my dreams away.
description: Judy is a cub villager who first appeared in Animal Crossing: New Horizons.

name: Julia
saying: Cut once, measure twice... Wait- reverse that.
description: Julia is a snooty ostrich villager in the Animal Crossing series. She first appeared in Doubutsu no Mori e+ as an islander, before returning in Animal Crossing: New Leaf - Welcome amiibo after nearly a decade of absence, this time as a villager, followed by an appearance in Animal Crossing: Pocket Camp. Julia's name could possibly be derived from "Jewel" or "Jewelry," both being things that relate to her snooty personality's elegant stereotype. Her initial catchphrase is the phrase "darling" with an English or Australian affectation, the former of which are stereotypically known to be refined, reserved, but sometimes condescending, again relating to the snooty personality. It is similar to the catchphrase of Baabara, another snooty villager.

name: Julian
saying: Never trot when you can prance.
description: Julian is a smug, horse villager in the Animal Crossing series. He was introduced in Animal Crossing: New Leaf, and was one of the first villagers announced for the release of the game. His name is derived from the Roman name 'Iulianus' and his birthday is the 15th of March: the day Julius Caesar was stabbed to death.

name: June
saying: Dream big, expect little.
