description: June is a normal cub villager from the Animal Crossing series. She is an islander in Animal Crossing and Doubutsu no Mori e+. She would later return in the Animal Crossing: New Leaf Welcome amiibo update. In the Prima Official Guide for Animal Crossing, her picture was replaced with Jane's.

name: Kabuki
saying:
If you make your opponent flinch, you have already won.
Hoo-ha konichiwa!
一声、ニ顔、三姿
description: Kabuki is a cranky, cat villager who has appeared in every Animal Crossing series game to date. He is named after the traditional Japanese plays of the same name, from which he also gets his ornate red patterning. His initial phrase, "meooo-OH", is a play on the word "meow", and a kabuki shout.

name: Katt
saying: MeowMEOWmeow!
description: Katt is a sisterly, cat villager in the Animal Crossing series. She first appeared in Animal Crossing: New Leaf. Her catchphrase may be a pun on the word "pretty" and the sound that cats make, "purr".

name: Keaton
saying: Even in a room full of fools, someone is the smartest.
description: Keaton is a smug, eagle villager in the Animal Crossing series who first appeared in Animal Crossing: New Leaf. His Japanese name is the same as the English name of another eagle villager, Frank.

name: Ken
saying: C'est la vie!
description:
Ken is a smug chicken villager in the Animal Crossing series. He first appeared in Animal Crossing: New Leaf. His picture quote, "C'est la vie!", is French for "that is life".
His English name is likely derived from "shuriken" since he initially wears a ninja shirt. His name may also be a reference to the last part of his species name.

name: Ketchup
saying:
When in doubt, eat a tomato!
酸いも甘いも
description: Ketchup is a peppy duck villager in the Animal Crossing series, who makes her debut in Doubutsu no Mori e+. She is absent in the Animal Crossing series until Animal Crossing: New Leaf's Welcome amiibo update, in which she can be moved into the player's town via her amiibo card. Her name comes from tomato ketchup (tomato sauce), a condiment used oftentimes on sandwiches. This also refers to her appearance, which resembles a tomato. Her English initial phrase is also the name of a snooty hippo villager.

name: Kevin
saying: Sometimes it's OK to get dirty.
description: Kevin is a jock, pig villager in the Animal Crossing series. He first appeared in Animal Crossing: New Leaf. His name is a reference to the American actor Kevin Bacon, and his catchphrase may be a reference to the children's nursery rhyme, "This Little Piggy."

name: Kid Cat
saying:
Crime doesn't pay!
Spandex is the best disguise.
必殺技!
description: Kid Cat is a jock cat villager in the Animal Crossing series. His name may come from his childish looks and attitude and that he is a cat. He is one of a few villagers who wear headgear such as helmets. He is also one of the five superheroes, the others being Agent S, Big Top, Rocket, and Filly. His name comes from his personality and his species. His initial phrase, psst, is a sound made when confiding a secret.

name: Kidd
saying: Be yourself - everyone else is already taken.
description: Kidd is a goat villager from the Animal Crossing series that first appeared in Doubutsu no Mori e+, as a lazy islander. He later reappeared in Animal Crossing: New Leaf, where he is a smug villager, and in Animal Crossing: Pocket Camp to launch the Civic Theme, alongside Gaston and Elise. His name comes from "kid," the name for a young goat.

name: Kiki
saying:
Nothing ventured, nothing gained.
Hang in there, kiddo.
女の心は猫の眼
description: Kiki is a normal, cat villager who has appeared in every Animal Crossing series game. Her name may come from Hayao Miyazaki's Kiki's Delivery Service, an animated film about a young witch-in-training named Kiki who has a black cat. Kiki may be a reference to the black cat, or it may come from the sound produced when saying "kittykitty" fast. Kiki appears on the cover of Animal Crossing: Wild World, near the bottom right.

name: Kitt
saying:
Funny parents have funny kids.
They say ugly parents have ugly children.
親馬鹿小馬鹿
description: Kitt is a kangaroo villager with a normal personality who appears in nearly all Animal Crossing series games, with the exception of Animal Crossing: Pocket Camp. Her name is likely derived from "pocket". Her Japanese name comes from appliqué.

name: Kitty
saying:
If you want something done well, do it yourself.
通販生活
description: Kitty is a snooty cat villager appearing in nearly all the games in the Animal Crossing series, except for Animal Crossing: Wild World and Animal Crossing: Pocket Camp. Kitty's name comes from the word "kitten," the infant form of adult cats. Her original catchphrase is "mrowrr," which looks similar to "meow," the sound cats make. It also looks similar to "more," which may reflect on the greedy lifestyle of a snooty villager.

name: Klaus
saying: Pride goes before a fall.
description: Klaus is a smug, bear villager introduced in Animal Crossing: New Leaf. His name is a reference to the "claws" of a bear and is derived from the Greek "Nikolaos". Befitting this, he has a Greek look to his appearance and his house.

name: Knox
saying: A man's coop is his castle.
description: Knox is a cranky, chicken villager in the Animal Crossing series that first appeared in Animal Crossing: City Folk. His name seems to be a play on Fort Knox, as his helmet is made of gold. His Japanese name is a reference to Kinkaku-ji, also known as the Golden Pavilion.

name: Kody
saying:
The sky's the limit!
Drop and give me twenty!
産地直送
description: Kody is a jock, cub villager in the Animal Crossing series, having appeared in every game so far. His English name is based off the kodiak bear.

name: Kyle
saying: Never trust a sheep in wolf's clothing.
description: Kyle is a smug wolf villager in the Animal Crossing series. He first appears in Animal Crossing: New Leaf. Both his English and Japanese names likely refer to the lycaon, also known as the African wild dog, which he bears a resemblance to.

name: Leonardo
saying:
That's the way the energy bar crumbles.
餅は餅屋
description: Leonardo is a tiger villager from the Animal Crossing series. He debuted in the Japan exclusive title Doubutsu no Mori e+, and then after being absent from Animal Crossing: Wild World and Animal Crossing: City Folk, reappeared in Animal Crossing: New Leaf. His name is a reference to a leopard, which he resembles. Likewise, his Japanese name comes from hyou, meaning leopard. His Japanese initial phrase, ja ga, means "though" and is a pun on jagā, meaning "jaguar."

name: Leopold
saying:
The bigger the first, the bigger your dinner.
本が嫌いな生徒には手で教えろ
description: Leopold is a lion villager in the Animal Crossing series. He debuted with a jock personality in Doubutsu no Mori, but this would later be changed to the smug personality in Animal Crossing: New Leaf - Welcome amiibo. His name is probably a reference to the lion's scientific name, Panthera leo as a wordplay with the Leopold surname. This may also refer to his species, a lion, who are called "Kings of the Jungle," and often referred to as "Kings."

name: Lily
saying: Don't jump to conclusions!
description: Lily is a frog villager in the Animal Crossing series with a normal personality. She has appeared in every Animal Crossing game to date. Her name is a reference to lily pads, a kind of plant that frogs are stereotypically known to occupy while in water. Her Animal Crossing: Wild World, Animal Crossing: City Folk phrase is a reference to the sound a frog is described to make. Her catchphrase was swapped with Ribbot until the 1.8.1 update for Pocket Camp, in which Lily reverts to her original catchphrase from Animal Crossing.

name: Limberg
saying:
Don't build a better mousetrap.
Something stinks!
ならぬ堪忍、するが堪忍
description: Limberg is a cranky mouse villager in the Animal Crossing series. His name is a shortening of Limburger cheese, a type of cheese with a strong odor, which may reflect his rough and unshaven appearance. His Japanese name comes from rakkyō, Chinese onion, similarly referencing a strong smell. His catchphrase, squinky, is a combination of the noise a mouse makes, squeak, and the word stinky.

name: Lionel
saying: Love is blind.
description: Lionel is a smug, lion villager new to Animal Crossing: New Leaf. His name, although a common name, relates to his species.

name: Lobo
saying:
If it's not one thing, it's another."
"I'm always watching you!
description: Lobo is a cranky wolf villager from the Animal Crossing series. His name comes from the Spanish and Portuguese word for wolf, which is also the Japanese name of another wolf villager. His initial phrase is based on the noise a wolf makes, a howl, which sounds like ah-rooooo.

name: Lolly
saying:
Laughter is the best medicine.
火事場のネコぢから
description: Lolly is a cat villager with a normal personality in the Animal Crossing series, who first appeared in Doubutsu no Mori e+. Her name and initial phrase relate to sweets (such as the lollipop), which refer to her personality, often called "sweet" instead of normal. She was absent in Animal Crossing: Wild World, but retured in Animal Crossing: City Folk. Her catchphrase, "bonbon," is "candy" in French.

name: Lopez
saying: Always look both ways before crossing the street.
description: Lopez is a smug deer villager from the Animal Crossing series. He first appeared in Animal Crossing: New Leaf. His name comes from "antelopes," animals that bear a resemblance to deer. His initial catchphrase is a play on "buck," meaning a male antelope or deer. His Japanese catchphrase is a play on "gazelle." In Animal Crossing: Happy Home Designer, he is one of the three mandatory clients in the game, the other two being Goldie and Carrie.

name: Louie
saying: It's all about the muscle.
description: Louie is a jock gorilla villager in the Animal Crossing series. His localized name in several languages, along with him originally wearing the Lil Bro's shirt before returning in Animal Crossing: Happy Home Designer, seems be a reference to Nintendo's character Luigi, from the Super Mario series and Mario's younger brother, in a similar fashion to Alfonso, whose design refers to the famous titular plumber. His initial phrase, "toots" may refer to when a gorilla releases a series of flatulence bursts, which is changed Yodel's catchphrase, "odelay." In Animal Crossing: Happy Home Designer, Louie was released as DLC on September 26th, 2015, where the player could get him at Nintendo Zones in celebration of the Super Mario series' anniversary, and from October 6th, 2015, Nintendo distributed him through SpotPass.

name: Lucha
saying: Birds of a feather, et cetera, et cetera...
description: Lucha is a smug bird villager in the Animal Crossing series, first appearing in Animal Crossing: New Leaf. His name is a reference to lucha libre wrestling, as he appears to be wearing a wrestling mask.

name: Lucky
saying:
Don't bite the hand that feeds you.
Ow...
description: Lucky is a lazy, dog villager from the Animal Crossing series, where he has made an appearance in every game. His name may be derived from his having a full body cast and being still alive, making him "lucky." Or, it could be used in an ironic tense, as he is unlucky enough to have a full body cast, but has the name "lucky."

name: Lucy
saying:
The best is yet to come.
This picture entitles you to one free smile!
description: Lucy is a normal, pig villager from the Animal Crossing series, appearing in nearly all the games except for Animal Crossing: Pocket Camp. Her initial catchphrase, snoooink, is based on the sound pigs make, oink.

name: Lyman
saying: Eucalyptus is the spice of life.
description: Lyman is a jock, koala villager in the Animal Crossing series. He is first introduced in Animal Crossing: New Leaf. His picture quote, “Eucalyptus is the spice of life," refers to his being a koala, as eucalyptus is the main part of a koala's diet. His name may come from the word "lime," referring to his green color.

name: Mac
saying: Sometimes life is rough.
description: Mac is a jock dog villager in the Animal Crossing series, who's debuted in Animal Crossing: City Folk.

name: Maddie
saying: The IT revolution is under way.
description: Maddie is a brown, peppy dog villager from the Animal Crossing series. After appearing in Doubutsu no Mori e+, Maddie remained absent until her return in Animal Crossing: Happy Home Designer, followed by an appearance in the Animal Crossing: New Leaf : Welcome amiibo update by scanning her amiibo card and visiting her at the Campground. Maddie's Japanese name, Marron, is the name of a chestnut dessert that is colored brown, referencing the color of her fur. It also sounds similar to a dog's howl. Her catchphrase, "yippee," is derived from "yip," an English onomatopoeia for a dog sound. "Yippee" as a stand-alone word is also an exclamation to convey excitement, referencing the nature of her peppy personality, which are depicted as energetic and overly excited. Her Japanese catchphrase, wantsū, comes from wan-wan, a Japanese onomatopoeia for a dog's bark, and wan tsū, the Japanese pronunciation of the English words, "one two."

name: Maelle
saying:
A wise duck takes care of her bill.
I like long walks on the beach. Alone.
description: Maelle, pronounced "Ma-Ell", is a snooty duck in the Animal Crossing series, debuting in Animal Crossing as an islander. She reappears in Animal Crossing: Wild World, Animal Crossing: City Folk, and Animal Crossing: New Leaf, where she is a villager. Her name, "Maelle", is French for "ambitious", a trait known among snooty villagers who wish to become famous or rich. Her Japanese name is also French, being the French pronunciation of "Anne." Her initial phrase, "duckling", reflects on her species. Her picture quote from Animal Crossing: Wild World may be a reference to when she was an islander.

name: Maggie
saying: All a plant needs is love...and sun and water and soil.
description: Maggie is a pig villager from the Animal Crossing series with a normal personality. She originally appeared in Doubutsu no Mori e+ as one of six starter villagers bundled with the game, alongside Walker, Rod, Merry, Angus, and Willow, respectively. Maggie would eventually return in Animal Crossing: New Leaf - Welcome amiibo after over a decade of absence, and later appeared again in Animal Crossing: Pocket Camp.

name: Mallary
saying:
Purple is the color of royalty.
Purple is the color of royalty, you know!
蛇からは蛇、蠍からは蠍が生まれる
description: Mallary is a snooty, duck villager from the Animal Crossing series. Her name comes from a species of duck, a mallard.

name: Maple
saying:
Waste not, want not.
Maple + Moppina = BFF!
description: Maple is a normal cub villager in the Animal Crossing series. She has appeared in every game so far. Maple's name comes from the type of tree called a maple tree, which are known to bear light-brown leaves, referring to Maple's fur color. She is the only character to mention another character in their picture quote, in this case, a mop called "Moppina."

name: Marcel
saying: There's not a dog so bad that he won't wag his tail.
description: Marcel is a lazy dog villager in the Animal Crossing series, who first appeared in Animal Crossing: City Folk. His English name and catchphrase are French, which come from his mime-like appearance. "Non" (which means "no") is a mild joke on the French way of speaking, since it is stereotypically used at the end of questions (e.g. "This shovel is used for digging up fossils, non?"). He is probably named after Marcel Marceau, a known French mime and actor. Despite this, his clothing, house, and Japanese name are traditionally Japanese themed; his face may be intended to resemble a Japanese festival mask.

name: Marcie
saying: The road to a friend's house is never long.
description: Not to be confused with Marcy.

name: Margie
saying:
Keep your feet on the ground.
色の白いは七難隠す
description: Margie is an elephant villager with a normal personality from the Animal Crossing series. As well as appearing in every game since Doubutsu no Mori e+, she appears in Doubutsu no Mori (film), where she is an aspiring fashion designer and is best friends with Ai.

name: Marina
saying: If you can't say something nice, don't say anything at all.
description: Marina is a normal, octopus villager whose debut appearance was in Doubutsu no Mori e+ as an islander. She later re-appeared in Animal Crossing: Wild World, Animal Crossing: City Folk, and Animal Crossing: New Leaf where she is a villager. She probably is named after marinas, which are sheltered harbors where boats are kept in the water. Her Japanese name, Takorina, has "tako" in it, which means octopus in Japanese. Her initial catchphrase is a reference to the onomatopoeia of an octopus squirting ink.

name: Marshal
saying: Seize the day.
description: Marshal is a smug, squirrel villager in the Animal Crossing series. He first appeared in Animal Crossing: New Leaf. His name is probably a reference to his marshmallow-like appearance, as well as being a common, male given name. His initial phrase, "sulky," may bear some resemblance to his appearance.

name: Mathilda
saying:
Nail polish is thicker than water. (NL)
Blood is thicker than water! (WW)
血の寄るものは親子
description: Mathilda is a snooty, kangaroo villager in the Animal Crossing series who has appeared in almost every game so far, except for Animal Crossing: Pocket Camp. Her name, as well as being a popular girl's name, especially in Australia, is a reference to "Waltzing Matilda," the unofficial national anthem of Australia, where kangaroos live. Her initial catchphrase, "wee baby," refers to her joey.

name: Megan
saying: Take a page out of someone else's book, if it's a good book.
description: Megan is a normal, bear villager from the Animal Crossing series. She first appeared in Animal Crossing: New Horizons. She is the first and currently only normal bear in the Animal Crossing series.

name: Melba
saying:
A friend who shares is a friend who cares.
You're my new best bud!
description: Melba is a normal, koala villager who first appeared in Animal Crossing: Wild World and subsequently in Animal Crossing: City Folk. Melba's English name may relate to the Australian city of Melbourne, also the Australian opera singer Dame Nelly Melba, who also represents her own ice-cream and Melba toast, which her phrase, "toasty," is a reference to - a dry, crisp, and thinly-sliced piece of toast that originated and is popular in Australia, where koalas are also from. Her Japanese name refers to the Australian city of the same name.

name: Merengue
saying: Life is a piece of cake.
description: Merengue is a normal rhino villager in the Animal Crossing series introduced in Animal Crossing: New Leaf. Her name comes from "meringue," a type of dessert, referencing her appearance, which resembles a cake. Her Japanese name comes from "pâtissière", a French word for a pastry chef. Her Japanese catchphrase, de shuga is a pun on desu ga, meaning "although," and shugā, the English word "sugar."

name: Merry
saying:
A smile increases your face value.
目病み女に風邪引き男
description: Merry is a peppy, cat villager from the Animal Crossing series. She first appeared in Doubutsu no Mori e+ as one of six starter cards bundled with the game, alongside Walker, Maggie, Rod, Angus, and Willow, respectively. Merry was absent from Animal Crossing: Wild World, but reappeared in Animal Crossing: City Folk. Her English name comes from "merry," having the same meaning as her Japanese name, and is also similar to the common given name "Mary."

name: Midge
saying:
When the world gets cold, just fly south.
あばたもエクボ
description: Midge is a normal bird villager in the Animal Crossing series. Midge's name is likely derived from "plumage," a word used to describe the color of a bird's feathers. Midge was also absent in Animal Crossing: Wild World, but returned in Animal Crossing: City Folk.

name: Mint
saying:
Always lead by example.
I’m totally fresh and you know it!
description: Mint is a snooty, squirrel villager from the Animal Crossing series, appearing in every installment to date. Mint gets her name from the color of her fur, which is mint green. Her picture quote and initial phrase also refer to mint and its common refreshing sensation.

name: Mira
saying: Always help a friend in need.
description: Mira is a sisterly rabbit villager who first appeared in Animal Crossing: New Leaf.

name: Miranda
saying:
If the world was flooded, it will be easy for the duck.
人を謗るは鴨の味
description: Miranda is a snooty duck in the Animal Crossing series that originally appeared in Doubutsu no Mori e+, and later returned in Animal Crossing: City Folk.

name: Mitzi
saying:
Practice makes purrrfect!
Sometimes I think I'm the only sane one around.
猫は三年の恩を三日で忘れる
description: Mitzi is a normal cat villager who has appeared in all the games in the Animal Crossing series. She appeared on the cover of Animal Crossing, standing in the upper window on the side with Punchy. She also appeared on the back of the Animal Crossing: City Folk cover.

name: Moe
saying:
Ignorance is bliss.
Whoa...
合縁奇縁
description: Moe is a lazy cat villager in the Animal Crossing series. His name possibly comes from the sound a cat often makes, or after the rare breed of cat (the Egyptian Mau) depending on the pronunciation of his name. Moe is also the Dutch word for ‘tired’ or ‘lazy,’ possibly referring to his personality type. His catchphrase, myawn, it a combination of the sound a cat makes, meow, and yawning, which reflects his lazy personality.

name: Molly
saying: Like water off a duck's back.
description: Molly is a normal duck villager, first appearing in Animal Crossing: New Leaf. Her name is likely derived from "mallard". Her Japanese catchphrase literally means "perhaps so," but is another play on kamo.

name: Monique
saying:
All publicity is good publicity!
No airbrushing necessary!
姿は作り物
description: Monique is a snooty cat villager in the Animal Crossing series. Monique is the name of several famous actresses, and it may also be a reference to Marilyn Monroe, whom Monique's appearance is based on. Her Japanese name, Jane, has also been worn by many actresses, but may specifically be in reference to Jane Russell. Her initial phrase, "pffffft", is the word given to the sound made when not caring, similar to sighing. Her Japanese name is another snooty villager's English name.

name: Monty
saying:
No news is good news.
What are YOU looking at?!
description: Monty is a cranky monkey villager from the Animal Crossing series, who first appeared in Animal Crossing: Wild World. He is currently the only cranky monkey in the games.

name: Moose
saying: A cornered rat will summon the courage to bite a cat.
description: Moose is a jock mouse villager, who first appears in Animal Crossing: City Folk. His name is a cross between his species, a mouse, and possibly from the hair product, mousse - possibly relating to his unique hair style.

name: Mott
saying: The lion's share goes to the lion.
description: Mott is a jock, lion villager in the Animal Crossing series. He was introduced in Animal Crossing: City Folk.

name: Muffy
saying: There's a black sheep in every family.
description: Muffy is a sisterly sheep villager in the Animal Crossing series. She first appeared in Animal Crossing: New Leaf. Her English name may come from the way her headpiece connects like a band to her horns, making it look like she is wearing earmuffs. Her Japanese name, Frill, references her Gothic Lolita style. Her catchphrase, "nightshade," refers to her black wool and the nightshade family of plants.

name: Murphy
saying: More money, more problems.
description: Murphy is a cranky cub villager from the Animal Crossing series. He originally appeared in games up to Doubutsu no Mori e+, in which Murphy would remain absent until he made a return in Animal Crossing: New Leaf - Welcome amiibo, alongside Olive, a fellow Cub villager. Originally, Murphy was planned to make an appearance in Animal Crossing: Happy Home Designer, but was absent from the final game.

name: Nan
saying: Nanny-nanny boo-boo!
description: Nan is a normal, goat villager who made her first appearance in Doubutsu no Mori e+, where like all other villagers who debuted in said game, could only be moved into the player's town by scanning her e-Reader card. Her name may be a shortened form of "nanny," another word for a female goat, and her catchphrase, "kid," could relate to a baby goat, which is called a kid. Her picture quote also has a play on words, Nanny Nanny boo boo is the skipping song.

name: Nana
saying:
Bread always falls peanut-butter side down."
"Pink is the new black!
description: Nana is a normal monkey villager from the Animal Crossing series. She debuted in Animal Crossing: Wild World. Her name comes from "banana". It may also reference a character from Ice Climber, further evidenced by her catchphrase, "po po" - Popo being another character from the same game. Her Japanese name may be a reference to Monchhichi, a brand of dolls resembling monkeys. She appears on the Animal Crossing: City Folk official poster. Her Animal Crossing: Wild World picture quote is the same as Flora's in Animal Crossing: New Leaf, but Flora's quote ends with a period instead of an exclamation point.

name: Naomi
saying: Moo like there's no tomorrow.
description: Naomi is a snooty, cow villager in the Animal Crossing series. She first appeared in Animal Crossing: New Leaf. Her catchphrase, "moolah," is a play on the slang word "moola," meaning "money." It is also similar to the catchphrase of Petunia, another snooty cow villager.

name: Nate
saying:
Be true to yourself.
誠実であれば最も遠くまで行く
description: Nate is a lazy bear villager in the Animal Crossing series. He first appears in Doubutsu no Mori and then in Animal Crossing and Doubutsu no Mori e+, but is absent in Animal Crossing: Wild World. He later returns in Animal Crossing: City Folk, however. His name most likely comes from hibernate, although he may also be named after Treehouse localizer Nate Bihldorf.

name: Nibbles
saying:
Appearances are, like, totally deceiving.
Coming to a billboard near you!
美人薄命
description: Nibbles is a peppy squirrel villager from the Animal Crossing series. Her name and initial phrase is derived from how squirrels eat their food.

name: Norma
saying: If you like what you have, then you'll have what you like!
description: Norma is a normal, cow villager in the Animal Crossing series. She debuted in Doubutsu no Mori e+, where she was an islander, and after being absent from the Animal Crossing series for over a decade, made a reappearance  in Animal Crossing: New Leaf - Welcome amiibo, as the sole normal cow in the game. Her name is a play on "Normal," her personality type.

name: O'Hare
saying: It's not old; it's vintage.
description: O'Hare is a smug rabbit islander in the Animal Crossing series who originally appeared in Animal Crossing under the cranky personality. O'Hare's name is derived from a hare, an alternate name for a rabbit, and the Irish surname O'Hare. His initial catchphrase, "amigo," comes from the word for "friend" in Spanish and Portuguese.

name: Octavian
saying:
Don't be a sucker!
月の裏側は秘密なのです
description: Octavian is a cranky octopus villager from the Animal Crossing series, first appearing in Doubutsu no Mori. The prefix of his name, "octa-," means eight, which is a reference to his species, which possess eight tentacles. His name is also a reference to Octavian (a.k.a. Augustus), the first emperor of ancient Rome. His Japanese is also prefixed with "octa-," and is derived from "tarou," which is a Japanese boys' name suffix. He is most notable for being the only octopus until Doubutsu no Mori e+, where Marina, a normal villager, appears as an islander. In Animal Crossing: New Leaf and Welcome amiibo, Octavian is also joined by Zucker and Inkwell, respectively.

name: Olaf
saying: Keep your nose clean.
description: Olaf is a smug, anteater villager in the Animal Crossing series. He appeared first in Animal Crossing: New Leaf. His name might come from the Spanish word "Olé!", an exclamation mostly heard in flamenco dancing and bullfighting, which also reflects his Hispanic appearance, but could also be derived from "olfactory", pertaining to sense of smell. His Japanese initial catchphrase is Spanish for "much" or "many."

name: Olive
saying: Sticky fingers attract bees.
description: Olive is a normal cub villager from the Animal Crossing series, making her debut in Doubutsu no Mori and its GameCube port, Animal Crossing. After Doubutsu no Mori e+, Olive would remain absent in the series until her return in Animal Crossing: New Leaf - Welcome amiibo, alongside Murphy. Her name is derived from the fruit of the same name, the olive, which are known to be sweet when eaten, referring to her normal personality (Normal villagers are occasionally referred to as "sweet" villagers instead of normal.) Olive's fur color is also similar in color to her namesake.

name: Olivia
saying:
There's an exception to every rule.
You're the best kind of friend because you make me look even prettier.
思えば思わるる
description: Olivia is a snooty, cat villager in the Animal Crossing series. Her name, Olivia, may refer to olives because an olive has a hard pit on the inside, and is somewhat bitter on the outside. This means that Olivia is hard and soulful on the inside, but can be bitter and mean on the outside. She has appeared in every game of the Animal Crossing series.

name: Opal
saying:
However little you think of an elephant, you can't say it won't fill a pot.
Now whenever you see this picture of me, you can think warm thoughts.
象に乗ってバッタとり
description: Opal is a snooty, elephant villager in the Animal Crossing series. She has made an appearance in every game to date. As a snooty villager, she will only have a sense for her own self-importance, making it difficult to relate and talk to her. Her name, "Opal", comes from the strong, turquoise gemstone which may reflect on her snooty personality, which revolves around glamour and status. Her phrase, "snoot," which means "nose" or "snob", may refer to her snooty personality (snob) and her trunk (nose).

name: Ozzie
saying: Half a loaf is better than none.
description: Ozzie is a lazy koala villager from the Animal Crossing series. His name is derived from the term "Aussie", which is another word for "Australian." His Japanese name means "acorn," referring to his nose.

name: Pancetti
saying: Always get it in writing.
description: Pancetti is a snooty pig villager in the Animal Crossing series. She first appeared in Animal Crossing: New Leaf. Her name refers to pancetta, Italian bacon made from salt-cured pork bellies. Her catchphrase "sooey" is a shout used in calling pigs on farms and elsewhere. It is also the nomenclature for another snooty pig villager.

name: Pango
saying:
A thing of beauty is a joy forever!
Now you can say you knew me when!
description: Pango is a peppy, anteater villager from the Animal Crossing series. She has appeared in every game so far. Her name is a shortening of pangolin, also known as the scaly anteater, a mammal that lives in tropical parts of Asia and Africa. However, pangolins are not actually anteaters, belonging instead to the group of animals known as pholidota.

name: Paolo
saying: When it works, it works.
description: Paolo is a lazy, elephant villager from the Animal Crossing series, originally appearing in Doubutsu no Mori and Animal Crossing, until he returned in Animal Crossing: New Leaf's Welcome amiibo Update. His name is the Italian form of "Paul," a given name derived from the Latin word for "small," most likely as a joke on his large size.

name: Papi
saying: Never say neigh.
description: Papi is a  lazy horse villager from the Animal Crossing series. He made his first appearance in Animal Crossing: New Leaf.

name: Pashmina
saying:
Before you judge someone, walk a mile in her hooves.
わざわいを転じて　福となす
description: Pashmina is a sisterly goat villager in the Animal Crossing series. She first appeared in Animal Crossing: New Leaf. Her name originates from the word "pashmina," which is the finest type of cashmere wool. The word pashmina also comes from the Persian word, pašmina, (پشمینه‎‎) which translates to "made of wool."

name: Pate
saying:
A duck won't bite you."
"SHRIEKING SUGARCUBES!
description: Pate is a peppy duck villager in the Animal Crossing series. She has appeared in almost every Animal Crossing game, except for Animal Crossing: Pocket Camp. Pate's name probably derives from pâté, a meat spread usually formed from the liver of a duck or goose.

name: Patty
saying:
A friend in need is a friend indeed!
This month's Ms. Nintendique cover girl!
言わぬことは聞こえぬ
description: Patty is a peppy, cow villager who has appeared in every Animal Crossing series game. Her name either relates to a "beef patty" or "cow pat" (another name for cow dung). Her Japanese name is likely from the milk-based soft drink Calpis. Her catchphrase is based on "How Now Brown Cow," a phrase that helps children learn rounded vowel sounds and is also a greeting.

name: Paula
saying:
Trends always make a comeback.
流行は回帰する
description: Paula is a bear villager from the Animal Crossing series. She first appears in Doubutsu no Mori e+ as a peppy villager and reappears in Animal Crossing: New Leaf with a sisterly personality.

name: Peaches
saying: Every day is a gift.
description: Peaches is a normal horse villager in the Animal Crossing series, appearing in every game except for Animal Crossing: Wild World and Animal Crossing: Pocket Camp. Her catchphrase, "neighbor," is a pun on the sound horses make.

name: Peanut
saying:
Never take a nibble when you can take a bite.
This is my star smile.
桃栗三年柿八年
description: Peanut is a peppy squirrel villager in the Animal Crossing series. As a peppy villager, Peanut will appear friendly and hospitable towards the player, making it easy to befriend her. Her name comes from peanuts, which squirrels are known to eat. Her Japanese name likely comes from momo, meaning peach; in addition to her color, this might refer to the Japanese proverb momo kuri san nen kaki hachi nen, which is also her favorite saying in the Japanese games.

name: Pecan
saying:
Promises are like pie crusts - they're made to be broken.
One picture of me is worth a thousand pictures of somebody else.
description: Pecan is a snooty, squirrel villager who has appeared in every Animal Crossing series game to date. Her name is derived from a type of nut. Her phrase is how chipmunks and squirrels are similar to each other, such as how they are both rodents.

name: Peck
saying: The best defense is a good offense.
description: Peck is a jock bird villager who debuts in Animal Crossing: New Leaf. His name simply comes from "pecking," a common behavior of birds. "pecs," which is pronounced like "pecks," is also an abbreviation for the pectoral muscles, referencing his jock personality.

name: Peewee
saying:
Look behind you.
I AM BEHIND YOU!
description: Peewee is a cranky, gorilla villager in the Animal Crossing series who has appeared in every game so far. His name is a joke on his size and personality - "peewee" usually indicating size with relation to youth when Peewee is in fact large and adult. His initial phrase, "Li'l dude," also relates to this. His name may also be related to 'Peewee Herman.'

name: Peggy
saying: We're all diamonds in the rough.
description: Peggy is a peppy, pig villager from the Animal Crossing series. She originally appeared in the Japanese-only Doubutsu no Mori e+, then returned in Animal Crossing: City Folk after being absent in Animal Crossing: Wild World. Peggy's name is a corruption of "piggy", an extensive, childish alternative of "pig", her species.

name: Pekoe
saying: Let bygones be bygones.
description: Pekoe is a normal cub villager from the Animal Crossing series. She first appeared in Animal Crossing: City Folk.

name: Penelope
saying: One mile or a thousand makes no difference to love.
description: Penelope is a peppy mouse villager in the Animal Crossing series. She is a new character, first appearing in Animal Crossing: New Leaf. Her initial phrase is a reference to her unique lack of ears and instead a bow. Her name is similar to that of Penny, another peppy mouse villager.

name: Phil
saying: Best not to say too much.
description: Phil is a smug ostrich villager in the Animal Crossing series, first appearing in Animal Crossing: New Leaf. He is currently the only smug ostrich. His name likely comes from "pheasant." His Japanese name may come from keen, a call made by male pheasants to advertise their territory. His initial phrase may be a reference to a bird's call. Similarly, his Japanese phrase is the cry of a pheasant.

name: Phoebe
saying: You can't keep a good bird down.
description: Phoebe is a sisterly ostrich villager in the Animal Crossing series. She first appeared in Animal Crossing: New Leaf. Both Phoebe's English and Japanese names are plays on the mythical phoenix, known as hinotori in Japanese. Hinoko can also mean "sparks".

name: Pierce
saying:
When someone says fly, you ask how high!
No one likes flabby wings!
鳶が鷹を産む
description: Pierce is an eagle villager in the Animal Crossing series with a jock personality. His name may relate to either his beak or his talons, which can pierce through the flesh of other animals in reality. His initial phrases relate to the bird species. His name and initial phrase may be a reference to the character Benjamin "Hawkeye" Pierce from the TV series "M*A*S*H", although this may be a coincidence.

name: Pietro
saying: Be the class clown!
description: Pietro is a smug, sheep villager in the Animal Crossing series. He first appeared in Animal Crossing: New Leaf. His name is derived from "pied," which means having a bright and multicolored patchwork appearance, referencing the color of his wool, or from "Pierrot" referencing his clown-like appearance. Similarly, his initial catchphrase is "honk honk," a common noise associated with clowns as they squeeze their bulbous nose to make noise. His Japanese catchphrase, gufufu, is a Japanese onomatopoeia for laughter.

name: Pinky
saying:
Time spent with friends is time well spent!
LEAPING LOLLIPOPS!
熱烈歓迎
description: Pinky is a peppy bear villager who has appeared in all Animal Crossing series games to date. As a peppy villager, she will be friendly towards the player, making it easy to befriend her. Her name relates to the color of her fur, which is pink, and her initial phrase, "wah" is another word for "what" which may relate to her character type, due to the fact that peppy villagers like her have a short attention span. The phrase may also relate to how, in Japan, wan is used for the sound that a panda makes. She is one of the villagers to appear on the cover of Animal Crossing, in the lower window on the side.

name: Piper
saying: When there's life, there's hope.
description: Piper is a peppy, bird villager from the Animal Crossing series. Her name and catchphrase allude to two different types of birds: her name is derived from the sandpiper, while her catchphrase is "chickadee". She was absent from Animal Crossing: Wild World and Animal Crossing: City Folk, but returns in Animal Crossing: New Leaf - Welcome amiibo.

name: Pippy
saying: Fake it till you make it.
description: Pippy is a peppy, rabbit villager in the Animal Crossing series. She has appeared in every game to date. Her name is a distortion of peppy, which reflects her bubbly and high-spirited personality.

name: Plucky
saying: Keep your crumbs out of the bed.
description: Plucky is a chicken villager from the Animal Crossing series. Her name comes from the word "pluck," meaning "to pull out feathers when preparing a bird for food." When she debuted in Animal Crossing, she was a peppy islander. After Doubutsu no Mori e+, Plucky would be absent from any Animal Crossing series media until she made an appearance in Animal Crossing: New Leaf - Welcome amiibo, this time as a sisterly villager.

name: Pompom
saying:
Happiness is a rainy day.
This one goes out to all my fans!
description: Pompom is a peppy, duck villager who has appeared in every Animal Crossing series game. Her name is derived from "pom-pom," a ball of fibers wielded by cheerleaders during sports, alongside her initial phrase "rah rah" - "rah rah" is a popular cheerleading chant. Many peppy villagers aspire to become cheerleaders, so it is likely her name and initial phrase make direct relation to the peppy personality.

name: Poncho
saying:
Fortune favors the brave!
C'mere! I wanna bench-press you!
description: Poncho is a jock cub villager that has appeared in every game from the Animal Crossing series to date. Poncho can be spotted on the front cover of Animal Crossing: City Folk. He's named after the traditional South American garment, the poncho; he may be based upon the spectacled bear, a diminutive species native to the Andean mountains and the only surviving species of bear in South America.

name: Poppy
saying: It's all about positive thinking!
description: Poppy is a normal squirrel in the Animal Crossing series, whose first appearance was in Animal Crossing: City Folk. Her name is a reference to either the poppy, a red flower, or poppy seeds, which are commonly used to make sweets and pastries. Her Japanese name is a reference to gummy candies, being the German-origin name for them in Japanese. Her catchphrase is a reference to one of squirrels' favorite foods, nuts. Poppy is one of the four normal villagers introduced in Animal Crossing: City Folk, alongside Gala, Bettina and Pekoe.

name: Portia
saying:
Charity begins at home.
Of course my photo doesn't need retouching!
description: Portia is a snooty dog villager who has appeared in nearly all of the games in the Animal Crossing series, except for Animal Crossing: Pocket Camp. She is also the only dog in the series that has a snooty personality. "Portia" is a common English name for individuals of high class, which references her snooty attitude. Her phrase, "ruffian" is a pun on "ruff," an onomatopoeia for the noise a dog makes, and a ruffian, a person who appears untidy.

name: Prince
saying:
Catch more flies with honey than vinegar.
深剃り三枚刃
description: Prince is a lazy frog villager in the Animal Crossing series. He was absent from Animal Crossing: Wild World, but reappears in later games. His name is based on fairy tale, The Frog Prince.

name: Puck
saying:
A bad attitude will land you in the penalty box.
馬鹿があればこそ利口が引き立つ
description: Puck is a lazy penguin villager in the Animal Crossing series. His name refers to a "puck," used in hockey games, which is played on ice, and ice is the habitat the typical penguin lives in. His Japanese name is literally the word Hockey. Due to his appearance as a hockey player, many players could mistake him for a jock villager. His favorite saying, "A bad attitude will land you in the penalty box," also references hockey. He is absent in Animal Crossing: Wild World, and he returns in Animal Crossing: City Folk. His initial phrase, brrrrrrrrr, is what people say when they are cold.

name: Puddles
saying:
Look before you leap.
HIP HOP HO! Hey, let's go!
description: Puddles is a peppy villager who appears in the Animal Crossing series. Her name relates to her species, a frog, which are known to sit in pools of water just as puddles. Her initial phrase, "splish," is the word associated with the sound of jumping in water, "splish, splash."

name: Pudge
saying:
There's no such thing as a free lunch.
Keep it real. Yeah.
魚はうまいが小骨が多い
description: Pudge is a lazy cub villager in the Animal Crossing series. Pudge's name and catchphrase are derived from "pudgy," an informal term for "fat," which may relate to his lazy personality.

name: Punchy
saying:
There's always more fish in the sea!
Turn the other cheek.
description: Punchy is a cat villager in the Animal Crossing series with a lazy personality. His name may come from the word "punchy," which means being groggy or dazed from a series of punches. His catchphrase is the sound of shrugging combined with sighing, which relates to his lazy personality. His picture quote from Animal Crossing: Wild World also relates to his personality, known for being laid back. Punchy was featured on the cover of Animal Crossing, in the upper window on the side with Mitzi, another cat villager.

name: Purrl
saying:
Let them drink cream.
You don't mind if I sharpen my claws on your bed, do you?
起きて半畳、寝て一畳
description: Purrl is a snooty, cat villager. She appears in all games from the Animal Crossing series. Calicoes have a myth of being a lucky type of cat, so Purrl can be suited as her name. Her name sounds similar to both the noise that a cat makes, "purr," and a gemstone prized for its elegance and shine, "pearl," referring to her "shiny and refined"-based personality. Her favorite saying, "let them drink cream," is a reference to “Let them eat cake”, a famous quote uttered by French noble-lady Marie Antoinette, although historical records have proven this to have never been said by her specifically.

name: Queenie
saying:
You never get a second chance to make a first impression.
No retouch necessary.
白を黒というのが人の常
description: Queenie is a snooty, ostrich villager in the Animal Crossing series. Her name does not directly link to her species or personality, but it can be said that snooty villagers see themselves as high up in the hierarchy, seeing themselves as royalty. Her name may also be a reference to Queensland in Australia, where emus, a similar animal to ostriches, can be found. Her initial phrase, "chicken," is a joke on her species, a chick being a member of the bird group as is her species, the ostrich. She is the only ostrich to appear in every game in the series.

name: Quillson
saying: There is beauty in everything.
description: Quillson is a smug, duck villager who first appears in Animal Crossing: New Leaf. His name comes from "quill," meaning the lower shaft of a feather, or a pen made from one. His phrase, "ridukulous," is a combination of the words "ridiculous" and "duck."

name: Raddle
saying:
A healthy mind makes for a healthy body.
病は気から
description: Raddle is a lazy frog in the Animal Crossing series. He made his debut in Doubutsu no Mori e+ as an islander, and then after being absent from any Animal Crossing series media for over a decade, made a reappearance in Animal Crossing: New Leaf - Welcome amiibo as a villager, and then reappeared in Animal Crossing: Pocket Camp. Raddle's name is likely derived from a "rattling cough," a term for violent, hard coughing, coughing relating to his doctor-like appearance. It may also derive from "radiology," a form of cancer treatment.

name: Rasher
saying:
Don't judge a book by its cover.
Stop looking at me with those hungry eyes! I'm not a pork chop!
この親にしてこの子あり
description: Rasher is a cranky, pig villager from the Animal Crossing series. As a cranky villager, he will appear more mature than other villager personality types and appear a bit arrogant towards the player. Rasher's name derives from the term "a rasher of bacon," with bacon being made from pigs.

name: Raymond
saying: Stay on brand!
description: Raymond is a smug cat villager whose first main series appearance was in Animal Crossing: New Horizons.

name: Renée
saying: Reckless youth makes rueful age.
description: Renée is a sisterly rhino villager in the Animal Crossing series. She was introduced in Animal Crossing: New Leaf and reappears in the spin-off game, Animal Crossing: Happy Home Designer. Her name is a play on "rhino". Likewise, her Japanese name is a play on sai, meaning rhinoceros.

name: Reneigh
saying: You can only be you, so be the best you that you can be.
description: Reneigh is a sisterly horse villager who first appeared in Animal Crossing: New Horizons. Her name seems to be a combination of the female given name "Renée" and "neigh", a loud noise similar to a squeal followed by a nicker made by horses. Her initial phrase, "ayup yup", is a generic term of agreement typically used while performing trivial tasks.

name: Rex
saying:
ビューティフルサンデー
Two wrongs don't make a right, but three rights make a left.
description: Rex is a lazy lion villager from the Animal Crossing series. His name comes from the Latin word "rex," which means "king," relating to the view that lions are "kings of the jungle." Rex's Japanese name refers to the day of Sunday, commonly known in Christianity as the sabbath, or day of rest. Alternatively, it could refer to the sundae, an ice cream dessert. As Rex is a lazy villager, this name is a reference to his personality.

name: Rhonda
saying: Don't look down your nose at people!
description: Rhonda is a normal, rhino villager in the Animal Crossing series, first appearing in Animal Crossing: Wild World. Her initial catchphrase may refer to the fact that rhinos, being large animals, have large feet.

name: Ribbot
saying:
Never rest, never rust.
休むことは錆びることだ
description: Ribbot is a jock, frog villager in the Animal Crossing series. His name is a portmanteau of the sound made by frogs ("ribbit") and the name of the human-like machine, a "robot."   He is one of the few villagers in the game who are not technically animals, along with Sprocket, Coco, Stitches, Bow, and Meow. He and Lily switched their catchphrases from Wild World until Pocket Camp 1.8.1 update.

name: Ricky
saying:
You gotta break a few shells to get to the nut.
私の親戚よりも私の歯
description: Ricky is a cranky, squirrel villager from the Animal Crossing series. He has appeared in the original Animal Crossing. He was removed from Animal Crossing: Wild World and Animal Crossing: City Folk, but reappeared in Animal Crossing: New Leaf. His name is also the Japanese name of Filbert.

name: Rizzo
saying:
Evil lurks everywhere.
家に鼠、国に盗人
description: Rizzo is a cranky, mouse villager in the Animal Crossing series, appearing in nearly all games except for Animal Crossing: Wild World and Animal Crossing: Pocket Camp. His English name is based on Rizzo the Rat from The Muppets.

name: Roald
saying:
You must learn to waddle before you can swim.
I'm not waddling! I'm working my glutes!
description: Roald is a jock penguin villager from the Animal Crossing series. He has appeared in every game so far. Roald is likely named after Roald Amundsen, a Norwegian polar explorer who led the first successful expedition to reach the South Pole, as well as being the first person to reach both poles. His Japanese name is derived from "penguin."

name: Robin
saying: Always keep your wings manicured so you can fly away!
description: Robin is a snooty bird villager in the Animal Crossing series. She has appeared in every Animal Crossing game to date. Her name and appearance are derived from robins, a type of bird. Her name is also the Japanese name for a lazy dog villager.

name: Rocco
saying:
The only thing to fear is fear itself... and bees.
You smell like patchouli!
十匹のカバは一つの穴に入れない
description: Rocco is a cranky hippo villager in the Animal Crossing series, who has appeared in every game so far. Rocco's name is likely a reference to "rocky", an adjective used to describe an obstinate or stubborn individual, in reference to his cranky personality. His English catchphrase is derived from his species, the hippo.

name: Rocket
saying: Art feeds the soul. So does pizza.
description: Rocket is a sisterly gorilla villager in the Animal Crossing series. She first appeared in Animal Crossing: New Leaf. Similar to Kid Cat, Agent S, Filly, and Big Top, Rocket is dressed as a superhero.

name: Rod
saying:
If you can't beat 'em, work harder.
You're not done 'til your muscles are screaming in agony!
description: Rod is a jock, mouse villager in the Animal Crossing series, debuting in Doubutsu no Mori e+ as one of the six villagers packaged with the game via e-Reader cards, alongside Walker, Maggie, Angus, Merry, and Willow. His name comes from "rodent," the biological order in which mice fall. Rod's initial phrase, "ace," means "to succeed easily" and "highest quality," relating to the competitive nature of jock villagers. It was also Ace's catchphrase.

name: Rodeo
saying: Zzzzzzzzzzzzz...
description: Rodeo is a lazy, bull villager who made his first appearance in Animal Crossing: Wild World. As a lazy villager, he will appear hospitable and friendly towards the player, making it easy to befriend him. He also has a fascination with food and super heroes. His name, Rodeo, comes from rodeo bulls, or bull-riding at rodeos, an event usually taking place in the US, where the rider aims to stay on the bull the longest while it is jumping and running. His initial phrase, "chaps," also relates to this. Chaps are an item of clothing, typically worn over jeans and made out of leather, which protect a rider from their trousers rubbing against their legs, otherwise causing irritation.

name: Rodney
saying: Everything is temporary.
description: Rodney is a smug hamster villager in the Animal Crossing series who made his first appearance in Animal Crossing: New Leaf. The English name "Rodney" could be a reference to a character that appears in the 1998 movie Dr. Dolittle.

name: Rolf
saying:
Don't skip lunch. Ever.
I could eat you for lunch, you know.
description: Rolf is a cranky, tiger villager who appears in the Animal Crossing series. His name is derived from "grrolf," an onomatopoeia for a tiger's growl. This word is also his initial catchphrase.

name: Rooney
saying: Bob and weave! Bob and weave!
description: Rooney is a cranky kangaroo villager in the Animal Crossing series. He first appeared in Animal Crossing: New Leaf. Along with Walt, he is one of the first male kangaroos to appear in the series, and was the very first to be revealed.

name: Rory
saying: Set 'em up and knock 'em down.
description: Rory is a jock, lion villager in the Animal Crossing series. He first appears in Animal Crossing: New Leaf and on said game's cover. Rory's design seems based on the traditional iconography of shishi, the Chinese architectural ornament also known as Imperial guardian lions. His name comes from the roar a lion makes.

name: Roscoe
saying:
Trouble rides a fast horse.
I've got my eye on you, bucko!
目は心の鏡
description: Roscoe is a cranky, horse villager in the Animal Crossing series. Roscoe is named after the award-winning jockey, Roscoe Goose. His initial phrase is a play on "neigh". Similarly, his Japanese phrase is the Japanese onomatopoeia for a horse sound, commonly known in English as a "whinny."

name: Rosie
saying:
One good purr deserves another.
To the president of the Rosie Fan club!
美貌は結婚まで、知恵は死ぬまで
description: Rosie is a peppy cat villager who appears in all games in the Animal Crossing series as well as in Doubutsu no Mori (film). Rosie will appear friendly, excitable, and hospitable towards other villagers and the player. Her name comes from the word "rose," a flower known for its sweet fragrance and symbolic significance in love, both relating to her peppy personality.

name: Rowan
saying:
Refuse to lose.
Why be junior varsity when you can be VARSITY?!
description: Rowan is a tiger villager in the Animal Crossing series who first appears in Animal Crossing as a cranky islander, then reappears in Wild World and all later games as a jock villager. This makes Rowan the first villager to have a personality change between games.

name: Ruby
saying:
You can always take the red-eye.
I'm not sick, I'm just Albino!
description: Ruby is a peppy rabbit villager in the Animal Crossing series. She first appeared in Animal Crossing: Wild World, where she appears on the cover.

name: Rudy
saying: Always land on your feet!
description: Rudy is a jock, cat villager in the Animal Crossing series. He first appeared in Animal Crossing: New Leaf. His English name may be a reference to Rudolph, a famous reindeer, who has a red nose like Rudy. His birthday, which is close to Christmas, wherein the iconic Christmas figure Santa Claus uses reindeer as a method of transportation, supports this theory. He shares his birthday with Isabelle and Digby. His picture quote is a reference to the popular phrase "cats always land on their feet."

name: Sally
saying:
Even the smallest acorn may grow into the tallest tree."
"Just something to remember me by.
description: Sally  is a normal, squirrel villager in the Animal Crossing series, appearing in almost all the games except for Animal Crossing: Pocket Camp. Originally appearing under the name Hazel in Animal Crossing, Sally replaces another squirrel villager, called Cally, who appeared in Animal Crossing; She is the first villager to have her English name changed. In Animal Crossing: New Leaf, a new squirrel called Hazel is also introduced. Her old name, "Hazel," relates to her species, which is commonly associated with nuts, as is her initial phrase, "nutmeg."

name: Samson
saying:
Squeak softly and carry a big stick.
This isn't a dress I'm wearing, it's a muscle tee.
description: Samson is a jock, mouse villager from the Animal Crossing series, who has appeared in all of the games so far, with the exception of Animal Crossing: Pocket Camp. His catchphrase, "pipsqueak", is based on the sound made by mice and the term "pipsqueak", which means "little". His Japanese catchphrase, "chū", is based on the Japanese onomatopoeia for a mouse's squeaking, "chūchū" (ちゅうちゅう).  His favorite saying in Animal Crossing: New Leaf is a pun on Theodore Roosevelt's famous quote "Speak softly and carry a big stick.", meaning to always be wary of your neighbors.

name: Sandy
saying: Soaring through the sky takes more than a pair of wings.
description: Sandy is a normal, ostrich villager from the Animal Crossing series, making her debut in Doubutsu no Mori. After being absent in all Animal Crossing media since Doubutsu no Mori e+, Sandy made a return in Animal Crossing: New Leaf - Welcome amiibo, although she was planned to make a reappearance in Animal Crossing: Happy Home Designer, but was cut for unknown reasons. Sandy also appears in Animal Crossing: Pocket Camp. Her Japanese name means "orchid."

name: Savannah
saying:
Keep your chin up!
サバンナで昼飯を食べる
description: Savannah is a horse villager in the Animal Crossing series with a normal personality. Her name comes from the natural habitat of zebras, a savannah.

name: Scoot
saying:
Some birds avoid the water; ducks look for it.
飛び出し注意
description: Scoot is a jock duck villager in the Animal Crossing series. He has appeared in nearly all of the games, except for Wild World and Pocket Camp.

name: Shari
saying: A good start leads to a good end.
description: Shari is a sisterly monkey villager in the Animal Crossing series. She first appeared in Animal Crossing: New Leaf.

name: Sheldon
saying: Winners don't quit, and quitters never win.
description: Sheldon is a jock, squirrel villager in the Animal Crossing series. He first appeared in Animal Crossing: New Leaf. His name may refer to the shell of a chestnut, the nut of which he bears a resemblance to. His Japanese name is a combination of kuri, "chestnut," and risu, "squirrel." His initial catchphrase, "cardio," refers to aerobic exercise, reflecting his jock personality. His Japanese catchphrase, like his name, is a reference to chestnuts.

name: Shep
saying: Even dogs won't get in the middle of true love.
description: Shep is a smug, dog villager who first appears in Animal Crossing: New Leaf. His name comes from "shepherd dog," which is reflected by his initial catchphrase.

name: Sherb
saying: Forty winks is never enough.
description: Sherb is a lazy goat villager who first appeared in Animal Crossing: New Horizons. His name is likely a play on "sherbet", a type of frozen dessert. Sherb's picture quote references his personality.

name: Simon
saying:
Friends go together like peanut butter and bananas.
It's kind of a stereotype, but I really do like bananas!
description: Simon is a lazy, monkey villager from the Animal Crossing series. His name probably comes from "simian". It may also be in reference to the game "Simon Says"; "Monkey see, monkey do," is a popular expression, and this expression relates to how the game "Simon Says" is played.

name: Skye
saying: Love makes the world go 'round.
description: Skye is a normal wolf villager who first appeared in Animal Crossing: New Leaf. Her name is derived from her appearance, which resembles the sky and clouds, while her phrase "airmail" refers to mail sent through the sky via airplane. Skye shares her Japanese name "Lily" with the frog villager Lily, and her catchphrase in Japan "fuwawa" sounds like "flower", in reference to her name "Lily". "Fuwafuwa" is also Japanese for "fluffy", much like her cloudy appearance.

name: Sly
saying: Don't bite off more than you can chew.
description: Sly is an alligator villager with a jock personality in the Animal Crossing series. He first appeared in Animal Crossing: New Leaf. His name is derived from his camouflage clothing and decorations which make him hidden. Similarly, his Japanese name comes from "hide."

name: Snake
saying:
A good ninja is neither seen, nor heard.
Snake's number one!
description: Snake is a jock rabbit villager in the Animal Crossing series. His name is an anagram of "sneak," reflecting his ninja-like appearance, though it may also be a reference to Solid Snake. His Japanese name likely comes from Momochi Tamba, a legendary ninja who founded the Iga school of ninjutsu. As the first two syllables of his Japanese name, momo also mean peach in Japanese, he could be intentionally designed to be partly pink. Snake's catch phrase in English might be a reference to both his species and his name. The phrase "bunyip" is a play on "bunny," and is also the name of a monster sometimes depicted with serpent-like characteristics in Australian Aboriginal mythology.

name: Snooty
saying:
Request forgiveness, not permission.
家は女が作るもの
description: Snooty is a snooty, anteater villager from the Animal Crossing series . Her name comes from the personality that she has, the snooty personality, as well as her large "snout." She debuted in Doubutsu no Mori, and, after being absent since Animal Crossing: Wild World, returned in Animal Crossing: New Leaf - Welcome amiibo.

name: Soleil
saying: Sometimes dreams are merely dreams.
description: Soleil is a snooty hamster villager in the Animal Crossing series. She first appeared in Animal Crossing: New Leaf. Her name is derived from the French word "soleil" which means "sun."

name: Sparro
saying: The proof of the pudding is in the eating.
description: Sparro is a bird villager in the Animal Crossing series, being a new character in Animal Crossing: New Leaf. He resembles a Eurasian tree sparrow, the common sparrow in the Eurasian continent including Japan.

name: Spike
saying:
Keep your eye on the ball.
初志貫徹
description: Spike is a cranky rhino villager in the Animal Crossing series. His name refers to the horn on his head, which could also be called a spike. Following his debut in Doubutsu no Mori, Spike would remain absent in all games past Doubutsu no Mori e+, before making a return in Animal Crossing: New Leaf - Welcome amiibo. Previously, however, Spike would have returned in Animal Crossing: Happy Home Designer, but was ultimately unused. Unused data of Spike could also be found in Animal Crossing: Pocket Camp prior to his inclusion in the game.

name: Spork
saying: It's never too late for a snack.
description: Spork, named Crackle in Australian and European English versions, is a lazy, pig villager from the Animal Crossing series. First appearing in Doubutsu no Mori, he was absent from Animal Crossing: Wild World, but reappeared in Animal Crossing: City Folk onward. His US name is a play on the word "pork," a bi-product of a pig. His PAL name, "Crackle," refers to "crackling," another bi-product of a pig. His Japanese name, "Polk," is a pun on "Pork," which is a homophone of "Polk" in Japanese. His initial phrase, "snork," is a combination of his name and the name given to the noise pigs make, "snort".

name: Sprinkle
saying: Frosting is just the icing on the cake.
description: Sprinkle is a peppy, penguin villager in the Animal Crossing series. Her Japanese name is based on the frozen dessert made with shaved ice, known as the frappé. Her English name is based on pieces of confectionery which are used to decorate cold desserts such as ice cream.

name: Sprocket
saying: Strike while the iron is hot.
description: Sprocket is an jock, ostrich villager in the Animal Crossing series. His name is a direct reference to a sprocket (a piece of machinery), or is possibly a portmanteau of "sprint" and "rocket." His Japanese name, Hertz, is a measurement of electromagnetic frequency, further referencing his status as a robot.

name: Static
saying:
Lightning never strikes twice. (NL)
Zap! (WW)
刺激のある人生を
description: Static is a cranky squirrel villager, appearing in every game in the Animal Crossing series. His name is based on the green and yellow lightning bolt that goes down his head. His catchphrase comes from the noise that arcing electricity makes.

name: Stella
saying:
100% Natural Fiber.
アクリル１００％
description: Stella is a normal, sheep villager from the Animal Crossing series. Her name comes from the Latin word stella, meaning star.

name: Sterling
saying: Discretion is the better part of valor.
description: Sterling is a jock, eagle villager from the Animal Crossing series. His first appearance was in Animal Crossing: City Folk, followed by Animal Crossing: New Leaf. His name comes from the "sterling silver," which is what his helmet is made out of. It can also be based on "starling," a type of bird. The name may also be a nod to the Sterling Renaissance Festival. His Japanese name is a reference to Ginkaku-ji, also known as the Silver Pavilion.

name: Stinky
saying:
If the mask fits, wear it!
闘魂
description: Stinky is a jock cat villager in the Animal Crossing series. His name may refer to his appearance which is usually associated with poor hygiene - dark green skin and underwear over his face. His initial phrase may have something to do with wrestling, a sound of strength and power. Stinky is absent in Animal Crossing: Wild World, but reappears in Animal Crossing: City Folk.

name: Stitches
saying:
One stitch in time saves nine!
Sometimes the sum is greater than its parts! Get it? A huh huh huh!
description: Stitches is a lazy, cub villager in the Animal Crossing series. He is based on a young child's worn stuffed animal, as indicated by his name and the many patches of fabric making up his body, which also explains his ownership of the Kiddie Series furniture. His phrase is based on the stuffing used in dolls and teddy bears.

name: Stu
saying: As a cow grows, so does its nostrils.
description: Stu, is a lazy bull villager from the Animal Crossing series. His name is presumably derived from the word 'stew,' a dish which often contains beef. He originally appeared in Animal Crossing, then returned in the Animal Crossing: New Leaf - Welcome amiibo update.

name: Sydney
saying:
Sail wherever the wind takes you.
朝焼けは雨、夕焼けは晴れ
description: Sydney is a normal, koala villager in the Animal Crossing series, who appears in Animal Crossing. She was absent in Animal Crossing: Wild World and re-appears in Animal Crossing: City Folk. Sydney is named after Sydney, the most populous city in Australia, which is the indigneous home of the koala.

name: Sylvana
saying:
Remember to see the forest between the trees.
胡蝶の夢
description: Sylvana is a squirrel villager with a normal personality from the Animal Crossing series, who makes her debut in Doubutsu no Mori e+. Although she was planned to reappear in Animal Crossing: Happy Home Designer, Sylvana was cut from the final game. She returns in Animal Crossing: New Leaf's Welcome amiibo Update, however. Sylvana's name is most likely derived from the Latin term 'silva,' which means 'forest.' This coincides with her favorite saying, which references the forest landscape.

name: Sylvia
saying:
Hop first; ask questions later.
親が親なら子も子
description: Sylvia is a kangaroo villager from the Animal Crossing series. She first appeared in Doubutsu no Mori e+ as a snooty villager and then reappeared in Animal Crossing: New Leaf as a sisterly villager. Additionally, she is the only sisterly kangaroo. Her initial catchphrase refers to the sound of hopping, which is a kangaroo's main method of locomotion.

name: T-Bone
saying: Don't have a cow.
description: T-Bone is a bull villager in the Animal Crossing series, who debuted in Animal Crossing with the lazy personality. After being absent from Animal Crossing: Wild World and Animal Crossing: City Folk, he reappeared in Animal Crossing: New Leaf as a cranky villager. He is named after the steak cuts of beef, t-bones. His catchphrase is a pun; a moocher is someone who asks by begging, while mooing is a bovine's onomatopoeia. His picture quote is a reference to one of Bart Simpson's catchphrases, "Don't have a cow, man!"

name: Tabby
saying:
You can never have too much of a good thing!
This is my new headshot!
description: Tabby is a peppy cat villager in the Animal Crossing series. Her name comes from the fact that she is a tabby cat. Her catchphrase is a portmanteau of "meow" and "wow."

name: Tad
saying: Take a leap!
description: Tad is a jock frog villager from the Animal Crossing series. His name likely comes from the word "tadpole," the name given to a young frog. Tad was, initially, absent in all games after Doubutsu no Mori e+, but later returns in Animal Crossing: New Leaf - Welcome amiibo, alongside fellow frogs Huck and Raddle.

name: Tammi
saying: Always be down to monkey around.
description: Tammi is a peppy, monkey villager in the Animal Crossing series. Her name derives from the simian known as the tamarin, likely the golden-mantled tamarin, based on her appearance.

name: Tammy
saying: If a job is worth doing, do it right!
description: Tammy is a sisterly cub villager in the Animal Crossing series, first appearing in Animal Crossing: New Leaf.

name: Tangy
saying:
"When life gives you lemons, make lemonade!"
"They say cats hate citrus. THAT REALLY HURTS MY FEELINGS!"
ストレート果汁１００％
description: Tangy is a peppy, cat villager that has appeared in almost every game in the Animal Crossing series, with the exception of Animal Crossing: Pocket Camp. Her name is derived from "Tangerine," a citrus fruit similar to oranges and clementines, as well as the adjective used to describe those fruits.  Her Japanese catch phrase, "mikan," means Tangerine.

name: Tank
saying:
Remember to keep your core muscles engaged!
灰色の足は、灰色の尻に勝る
description: Tank is a jock rhino villager who appears in all games in the Animal Crossing series and is the only rhino villager to do so. His name may come from a type of tank called a "Rhino Tank," which also references his species. His name may also be a reference to a tank-top shirt, which is commonly used when exercising, matching his jock personality.

name: Tasha
saying:
There's no such thing as a safe secret.
石の物言う世の中
description: Tasha is a snooty squirrel from the Animal Crossing series. She made her debut in Doubutsu no Mori e+, which would be her only appearance in any Animal Crossing series media until she made a reappearance in Animal Crossing: New Leaf - Welcome amiibo. This was later followed by an appearance in Animal Crossing: Pocket Camp, as one of several villagers unlockable through Blathers's Treasure Trek.

name: Teddy
saying:
No pain, no gain!
You gotta play through the pain!
太平の功は一人の力に非ず
description: Teddy is a jock bear villager who appears in every game in the Animal Crossing series. His name refers to his species and the stuffed toy called a teddy bear. His catchphrase is "grooof," which refers to growling, a sound made by various animals, and in this case a bear.

name: Tex
saying: Rules were made to be broken.
description: Tex is a smug penguin villager who debuted in Animal Crossing: New Leaf. His catchphrase, "picante," is Spanish for "spicy,"[1] which contrasts with cold, something which penguins are associated with.

name: Tia
saying:
Tea is a cup of life.
ティーパーティー
description: Tia is an normal, elephant villager in the Animal Crossing series. She first appeared in Animal Crossing: New Leaf. The first syllable of her name is pronounced the same as "tea." Her catchphrase "teacup" and her name refer to the teapot-like appearance of her head.

name: Tiffany
saying:
What is cheap is most costly.
What's up, bun bun?
鬼面の仏
description: Tiffany is a rabbit villager with a snooty personality. She is a new character who first appeared in Doubutsu no Mori e+, a Japanese only game, then reappeared in Animal Crossing: Wild World and every game since. Her initial phrase, bun bun, is a reference to the word "bunny." Her name is the same as the Japanese version of Celia, another villager.

name: Timbra
saying: Don't pine for the past.
description: Timbra is a snooty sheep villager in the Animal Crossing series. She first appeared in Animal Crossing: New Leaf. Her name is a pun on "timber," what people usually say when a tree falls down. Her catchphrase and favorite saying also relate to this.

name: Tipper
saying:
It takes two to tango.
I know you'll treasure this forever.
description: Tipper is a snooty cow villager in the Animal Crossing series. She first appeared in Animal Crossing: Wild World. Her name is derived from cow tipping, the activity of sneaking up to a sleeping, upright cow and pushing it over for fun. Her catchphrase, "pushy," may also refer to this. Her Japanese name, Makiba, means "ranch."

name: Tom
saying:
There's no use crying over spilled milk.
必殺技はネコパンチ
description: Tom is a cranky cat villager in the Animal Crossing series, appearing in almost all the games except for Animal Crossing: Wild World. His name is based on tomcats, another name for male cats. His Japanese name, Bantam, is short for "bantamweight," a weight division in sports such as boxing.

name: Truffles
saying:
The best things in life are free.
JUMPING JELLYBEANS!
description: Truffles is a peppy pig villager from the Animal Crossing series. Her name is a reference to the edible fungus called truffles, a food that is common in a pig's diet and found hidden underground.  Her Japanese name, Tonko, may be short for Tonkotsu, a dish made with pork belly and bones, simmered with miso, sake and vegetables.  It is also a type of Ramen. Alternatively, it could be from ton, "pork," and ko, a Japanese girls' name suffix. Her catchphrase, "snoutie", may relate to her snout.

name: Tucker
saying: Time makes fossils of us all.
description: Tucker is an elephant villager in the Animal Crossing series. He first appears in Animal Crossing: New Leaf. His name may be derived from "tusks," a physical feature of elephants and mammoths, or, alternatively, it could come from the saying "tucker out," used for when someone is falling asleep easily, in reference to his lazy personality.

name: Tutu
saying: Even best friends start out as strangers!
description: Tutu is a peppy bear villager from the Animal Crossing series, appearing in nearly all of the games apart from Animal Crossing: Wild World and Animal Crossing: Pocket Camp. According to her e-Card bio, Tutu is from the North Pole, which relates to the fact she is a polar bear.

name: Twiggy
saying:
It's the early bird that catches the worm!
Do you want my autograph, too?
迷わず行けよ、行けばわかるさ
description: Twiggy is a peppy bird villager who appears in all games from the Animal Crossing series. Her name may be derived from birds using twigs to build their nests, though she may also be named after the model Twiggy, who was nicknamed 'Twiggy' because of her physique. Peppy villagers like Twiggy desire to be famous, so this may be related to her peppy personality.

name: Tybalt
saying: There's no excuse for half-baked potatoes.
description: Tybalt is a jock, tiger villager from the Animal Crossing series, who appears from Doubutsu no Mori until Doubutsu no Mori e+, after which he would not appear again until Animal Crossing: New Leaf - Welcome amiibo, being mostly replaced by Rowan, another tiger who was given the jock personality in Animal Crossing: Wild World. The name Tybalt is most likely taken from William Shakespeare's Romeo and Juliet, being named after the character of the same name. This is especially considering that another character in the play makes a scene of nicknaming Tybalt the "King of Cats," which in itself is a reference to Tybalt/Tibert the Cat from the story of Reynard the Fox. His Japanese name is the alias of the Japanese bandit Tani Yukata who was active in Malaya, Harimau, which is Malay for "tiger."

name: Ursala
saying: Surround yourself with things you love.
description: Ursala is a bear villager from the Animal Crossing series, appearing in Animal Crossing and Doubutsu no Mori e+ as a snooty villager, after which she would not appear in another Animal Crossing series game for a long time. She was planned to reappear in Animal Crossing: Happy Home Designer, but was cut from the game, though she returns in Animal Crossing: New Leaf's Welcome amiibo update, now as a sisterly villager. Her name comes from the Latin and Portuguese word "ursa," which means "bear," and female name, "Ursula."

name: Velma
saying:
Work smarter, not harder.
一流、名門、エリート
description: Velma is a snooty goat villager from the Animal Crossing series. Her name, and even her appearance, may be based on the Scooby-Doo cartoon character named Velma Dinkley. Her catchphrase, "blih," is probably from the noise goats make.

name: Vesta
saying:
No sweater off my back.
I'm so lucky to have this wool coat!
羊をなくしてから庭に柵
description: Vesta is a normal sheep in the Animal Crossing series that has appeared in every Animal Crossing game to date. Her name is a play on the word vest, an item of clothing sometimes made out of the wool of sheep, her species, and 'Vesta', the Roman goddess of hearth, home and fire (Greek equivalent to Hestia). Her initial phrase, baaaffo is a play on the word baa, the sound sheep make.

name: Vic
saying: You mess with the bull, you get the horns.
description: Vic is a bull villager with a cranky personality. He first appeared in Animal Crossing: New Leaf. His name refers to the Vikings.

name: Victoria
saying:
Don't put the cart before the horse.
CATERWAULING CARROT CAKE!
小船の宵ごしらえ
description: Victoria is a peppy horse villager who appears in the Animal Crossing series, being introduced in Doubutsu no Mori e+, and appearing in every game up to Animal Crossing: New Leaf - Welcome amiibo since that point. Considering she looks like a race horse, her name may simply relate to "victory". It could also come from the Victoria Derby, or the famous racehorse Victoria Park. Her Japanese name has been the name of several racehorses, as well as sounding similar to "centaur." Her initial phrase relates to sugar cubes being given to horses as a treat. This catchphrase is very similar to Cleo's catchphrase.

name: Violet
saying: Pearls are a pink gorilla's best friend.
description: This article refers to the villager. For information on a type of flower, please see here.

name: Vivian
saying:
Onwards and upwards!
スーツは裏地に凝れ
description: Vivian is a wolf villager with a snooty personality from the Animal Crossing series. She first appeared in Animal Crossing's Japanese Doubutsu no Mori e+ update, and then returned in the Animal Crossing: New Leaf  Welcome amiibo update after being absent from the Animal Crossing series for over ten years.
