Additionally, she was planned to return in Animal Crossing: Happy Home Designer, as data for her can be found in the game, but she is absent from the final game.

name: Vladimir
saying:
Trouble never comes alone.
武士は食わねど高楊枝
description: Vladimir is a cranky, cub villager from the Animal Crossing series. "Vladimir" is a traditional Russian name, and "nyet", Vladimir's catchphrase, is Russian for "no". He was absent in Animal Crossing: Wild World, but reappeared in Animal Crossing: City Folk.

name: Wade
saying:
Which came first, the seeds or the sunflower?
卵が先か鶏が先か
description: Wade is a lazy, penguin villager from the Animal Crossing series. He made his debut in Doubutsu no Mori e+ and would remain absent from the Animal Crossing series after his initial appearance for over a decade, until he made a reappearance in Animal Crossing: New Leaf - Welcome amiibo.

name: Walker
saying:
The dog wags his tail, not for you, but for your bread.
動かざること山の如し
description: Walker is a lazy, dog villager in the Animal Crossing series who first appeared in Animal Crossing's Doubutsu no Mori e+ update as one of six starter cards bundled with the game, alongside Maggie, Rod, Merry, Angus, and Willow, respectively. His name relates to walks, or walking, which dogs are known to enjoy. His initial phrase, "wuh," relates to his personality type, which means "what" in a dazed expression. His Japanese catchphrase is shared with Bow, another lazy dog villager that appears in Doubutsu no Mori e+. He is also the only dog from e+ to ever return in another Animal Crossing series game.

name: Walt
saying: Take the good with the bad.
description: Walt is a cranky kangaroo villager in the Animal Crossing series. He first appeared in Animal Crossing: New Leaf. His name may be a reference to the famous Australian song "Waltzing Matilda". His name may also be derived from Walt Disney who first drew the kangaroo mascot for the University of Missouri - Kansas City, Kasey the Kangaroo.

name: Wart Jr.
saying:
Age before beauty.
I've got my eye on you.
蛙のいるところ水あり
description: Wart Jr. is a cranky frog villager in the Animal Crossing series. His name relates to the myth that frogs, or commonly toads, have warts and pass them through contact. His name may also be a reference to Wart, a frog character in the Mario series, which is referenced to throughout the Animal Crossing franchise. His initial phrase, "gir-ribbit," is the sound a frog makes.

name: Weber
saying:
Today's adults are yesterday's children.
鼻たれ小僧も大人になる
description: Weber is a lazy duck villager from the Animal Crossing series. he made his debut in Doubutsu no Mori, and then appeared in all installments up to Doubutsu no Mori e+. After being absent from any Animal Crossing series media for over a decade, Weber made a reappearance in Animal Crossing: New Leaf - Welcome amiibo. Additionally, data for Weber was found in Animal Crossing: Happy Home Designer, but he was not present in the final game. His name is a play on web, since ducks have webbed feet.  His catchphrase, "quaa", is a play on quack, the sound a duck makes.  His Japanese catchphrase, "piyo," is the onomatopoeia for peeping, a sound that young birds make.

name: Wendy
saying: Every cloud has a silver lining.
description: Wendy is a sheep villager with a peppy personality in the Animal Crossing series, first appearing in Animal Crossing: City Folk. Her name may come from the word "windy," due her to weather-related quote, and her wool and horns resembling a dark cloud with lightning bolts. Likewise, her Japanese name means "sleet".

name: Whitney
saying:
Don't cry wolf unless you mean it.
If you even THINK about crossing me, just think about these pearly whites!
description: Whitney is a snooty, wolf villager from the Animal Crossing series, appearing in every game since Animal Crossing: Wild World, plus in Doubutsu no Mori (film). Whitney's name comes from the fact that her fur color is white.

name: Willow
saying:
You can't fight your genes. NA 
 血は争えぬ JP
description: Willow is a snooty sheep villager in the Animal Crossing series. She first appeared in Doubutsu no Mori e+ as one of six starter cards bundled with the game, alongside Walker, Maggie, Rod, Merry, and Angus, respectively. Although she is absent in Animal Crossing: Wild World, she later reappears in Animal Crossing: City Folk, her debut in a game released to the west. Willow's name may be derived from the golden willow, a variant of the white willow, referring to her golden wool. Her catchphrase comes from the nursery rhyme Little Bo Peep.

name: Winnie
saying: Smile, and the world smiles with you.
description: Winnie is a peppy, horse villager from the Animal Crossing series. She was absent from Animal Crossing: Wild World and returns in Animal Crossing: City Folk. Her name is a reference to whinnying, an onomatopoeia for the sound a horse makes, and the given name Winnie. Her catchphrase is a combination of the words "hay" and "A-OK." She can be seen in the cover of Animal Crossing: City Folk under a tree reading a book.

name: Wolfgang
saying:
Don't be afraid to show your fangs.
I could eat you for breakfast, short stack!
見えてる村へは案内不要
description: Wolfgang is a cranky, wolf villager who has appeared in every game from the Animal Crossing series. His name is derived from the famous composer, Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart, and from his species. His Japanese name, Lobo, is Spanish for wolf; it also is the English name for another wolf. He appears on the album cover of "K.K. Adventure." His initial catchphrase refers to snarling, the sound a wolf makes when it is angry, fitting both his species and his personality.

name: Yuka
saying:
Beauty is in the eye of the beholder.
It's nice that you have me as a friend.
description: Yuka is a snooty koala villager in the Animal Crossing series. Both her English and Japanese names come from eucalyptus, which koalas eat the leaves of.

name: Zell
saying: Clothes totally make the man.
description: Zell is a smug, deer villager who first appeared in Animal Crossing: New Leaf, as one of the first ten deer villagers in the Animal Crossing series. His name comes from "gazelle."

name: Zucker
saying: There's no such thing as luck.
description: Zucker is a lazy octopus villager in the Animal Crossing series. He first appeared in Animal Crossing: New Leaf and was one of the first new villagers announced for that game. His English name comes from ‘sucker,’ like those found on an octopus's tentacles, while his Japanese name and overall appearance refer to takoyaki, a popular Japanese food made with octopus. Zucker shares his catchphrase with Bertha, a normal hippo villager.
